سورہ الحدید (57: 5) میں ، اللہ نے اعلان کیا ، *"لاہو ملکو السوتی وا الیئرڈ" *-اس کا آسمان اور زمین کا غلبہ ہے۔ یہ آیت *توحد *کے بنیادی اسلامی اصول کی تصدیق کرتی ہے ، اور تخلیق پر اللہ کی مطلق خودمختاری پر زور دیتی ہے۔ اصطلاح * ملکو * (ڈومینین) نہ صرف ملکیت بلکہ فعال حکمرانی کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے ، جو تخلیق شدہ مخلوقات کے لئے آزاد طاقت کے کسی بھی تصور کو مسترد کرتی ہے۔ تاریخی طور پر ، اس مدین آیت نے ابتدائی مسلمانوں کو سیاسی اور معاشرتی اتار چڑھاؤ کا سامنا کرنا پڑا ، اور انہیں یاد دلاتے ہوئے کہا کہ حقیقی اختیار صرف قبائلی رہنماؤں یا دنیاوی نظاموں کے ساتھ نہیں ہے۔ اس نے اسلام سے قبل عرب ذہنیت کا مقابلہ کیا جس نے الہی مرضی کو مرکز کے ذریعہ تمام طاقت کا ذریعہ بنا کر قبائلی فخر (*آسابیہ*) کو ترجیح دی۔

جملے *ترجاؤ الومور *(معاملات واپس کردیئے گئے ہیں) *ماڈ * *-فیصلے کے دن اللہ کی آخری واپسی پر یقین کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے۔ شیعہ طافسیر ، جیسا کہ علامہ تبتابائی جیسے اسکالرز نے سمجھایا ہے ، اس کو الہی انصاف (*‘ADL*) کے تصور سے جوڑتا ہے ، جہاں اللہ کی ابدی حکمت کے تحت ہر عمل کا حساب کتاب ہوتا ہے۔ عصری مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت گہری یقین دہانی پیش کرتی ہے: عالمی عدم استحکام یا ذاتی آزمائشوں کے درمیان ، اپنے منصوبے میں اللہ کے ڈومینین فوسٹرز ٹرسٹ (*توقکول*) کو تسلیم کرتے ہوئے۔ اس میں مومنین کو اپنے فیصلوں کا مطالبہ کیا گیا ہے - چاہے وہ حکمرانی ، اخلاقیات ، یا روزمرہ کی زندگی میں ، الہی رہنمائی کے ساتھ ، بدعنوان نظاموں کو مسترد کرتے ہیں جو اللہ کے قوانین پر انسانی خواہشات کو ترجیح دیتے ہیں۔ عملی طور پر ، اس کا مطلب قرآنی اصولوں کے ذریعہ انصاف کی تلاش ، عاجزی کے ساتھ زندگی کے امتحانات کو قبول کرنا ، اور دنیاوی اختیار کو خالق کے لئے عارضی اور جوابدہ سمجھنا۔ اس سچائی کو اندرونی بناتے ہوئے ، مسلمان روحانی وضاحت کے ساتھ جدیدیت پر گامزن ہوسکتے ہیں ، اور یہ جانتے ہوئے کہ ہر نتیجہ اللہ کے ہاتھوں میں ہے۔
5.layer2_urdu:
سورہ الحد 5 میں ، یہ اعلان "ان کا آسمانوں اور زمین کا غلبہ ہے" اللہ کی مطلق خودمختاری (المولک الموتلاق) کو قائم کرتا ہے ، جو شیعہ الہیات کا ایک سنگ بنیاد ہے جس میں توہد الروبوبیا (لارڈشپ میں وحدانیت) پر زور دیا گیا ہے۔ کلاسیکی مبصرین جیسے شیخ تبریسی * مجسما البیان * میں یہ واضح کرتے ہیں کہ "ڈومینین" یہاں آنٹولوجیکل ملکیت (تمالوک تکوینی) اور قانون سازی اتھارٹی (تمالوک تاشریئ) دونوں کو شامل کرتا ہے ، اور اس نے اللہ کے علاوہ کسی بھی آزاد ایجنسی کو مسترد کردیا ہے۔ یہ شیعہ کے اللہ کی تخلیق پر حکمرانی کے خصوصی حق پر اصرار کے ساتھ منسلک ہے ، جو انسانی یا آسمانی بیچوانوں کو خود مختار طاقتوں کی حیثیت سے نظرانداز کرتا ہے۔

"اللہ کو تمام معاملات واپس کردیئے گئے ہیں" (وا اللہ اللہ ترجاؤ الومور) کی ترجمانی الامہ تبتابائی نے * المزان * میں کی ہے جس کی تصدیق دونوں ہی اسکیٹولوجیکل ریٹرن (ما ad ا) اور تمام کارگر زنجیروں (آسباب) کی فوری انحصار پر الہی مرضی پر ہے۔ شیعہ استثنیٰ نے اس بات پر زور دیا ہے کہ اگرچہ ثانوی وجوہات تخلیق کے اندر کام کرتی ہیں ، ان کی افادیت اللہ کے مستقل رزق (امداد) پر مکمل طور پر ہنگامہ خیز (بِتھت المکن) ہے۔ اس سے الہی مداخلت سے آزاد قدرتی وجوہات کے شیعہ کو مسترد کرنے کی نشاندہی کی جاتی ہے۔

خاص طور پر ، شیعہ اسکالرز اس آیت کو امامہ کے نظریے سے مربوط کرتے ہیں۔ اللہ کی طرف معاملات کی "واپسی" کو اماموں کے کردار کے عینک کے ذریعہ سمجھا جاتا ہے جیسے اللہ کے قیام کے مقرر کردہ متولیوں (ہوجج) کے طور پر۔ جیسا کہ امام جعفر السادق کی روایات میں بیان کیا گیا ہے ، اے ایچ ایل ال بیت "گیٹ ویز" (ابواب) ہیں جس کے ذریعے الہی کمانڈ (اے ایم آر) تخلیق کی طرف راغب کیا جاتا ہے ، جس سے ان کا ولیہ اللہ کے تسلط کی حقیقت سے الگ الگ ہوتا ہے۔ یہ امام کے آنٹولوجیکل اسٹیشن کے ذریعہ الہی ماورائی (تنزیہ) اور امنسی (تشبیہ) کے شیعہ ترکیب کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔

فقہی طور پر ، یہ آیت شیعہ اصول کو تقویت دیتی ہے کہ تمام قانون ساز اتھارٹی صرف اللہ سے حاصل ہوتی ہے ، اور اس سے مکمل طور پر نبی اور اماموں کو گورننس (Wilayat al-amr) کی تفویض کرتے ہیں۔ اس طرح ، سیاسی اور مذہبی اتھارٹی جو الہی عہدہ (NASS) میں جڑی نہیں ہے اسے ناجائز سمجھا جاتا ہے۔ الہی خودمختاری کا آیت کا جامع وژن اس طرح شیعہ کائناتولوجی ، اسکیٹولوجی ، اور قانونی نظریہ کو غیر سنجیدہ توحید میں لنگر انداز کرتا ہے۔
5.layer3_urdu:
عصری شیعہ اسکالرشپ میں ، سورہ الحد 57: 5 کو اکثر الہی خودمختاری اور انسانی احتساب کی گہری یاد دہانی کے طور پر تیار کیا جاتا ہے۔ آیت اللہ ناصر مکارم شیرازی نے اپنے *طافسیر نمونہ *میں ، اس بات کی نشاندہی کی ہے کہ تخلیق کے بارے میں اللہ کے غلبے کے اعلان کو جدید مادیت پسند دنیا کے نظارے کو چیلنج کیا گیا ہے ، اور مومنین پر زور دیا گیا ہے کہ وہ کائناتی اور معاشرتی نظام دونوں میں خدائی نظم و ضبط کو تسلیم کریں۔ یہ کائناتی ٹھیک ٹوننگ پر سائنسی مباحثوں کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہے-یہ خیال کہ کائنات کے جسمانی استحکام کو زندگی کے لئے خاص طور پر کیلیبریٹ کیا جاتا ہے-جو ایک ماہر طبیعیات اور مذہبی ماہر ڈاکٹر مہدی گولشانی جیسے اسکالرز اللہ کے جان بوجھ کر ڈیزائن کی عکاسی کے طور پر تشریح کرتے ہیں۔ آیت کا یہ دعویٰ ہے کہ "تمام معاملات اللہ کی طرف لوٹتے ہیں" ماحولیاتی اخلاقیات کے ساتھ گونجتے ہیں ، جیسا کہ ڈاکٹر محمد علی شمالی جیسے معاصر شیعہ مفکرین ماحولیاتی ذمہ داری کو ماحولیاتی ذمہ داری سے زمین کے * خلیفہ * (ٹرسٹی) کے کردار سے مربوط کرتے ہیں ، جو آب و ہوا کے بحرانوں کے درمیان استحکام پر زور دیتے ہیں۔  

معاشرتی طور پر ، آیت طاقت کے ڈھانچے پر تنقید کرتی ہے جو انسانی ہاتھوں میں اتھارٹی کو مرکزی حیثیت دیتی ہے ، یہ ایک موضوع سید عمار نکشوانی جیسے اسکالرز کے ذریعہ گونجتا ہے ، جو اسے آمریت پسندی اور معاشی عدم مساوات کے خلاف جدید جدوجہد سے جوڑتا ہے۔ فلسفیانہ طور پر ، اللہ کی طرف "واپسی" وجودی اضطراب کے دور میں زندگی کے مقصد کی عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے ، جس میں نحل کو متضاد بیان کرنے کی پیش کش کی جاتی ہے۔ بین المذاہب مکالمے ، خاص طور پر یہودی اور عیسائی روایات کے ساتھ جو الہی خودمختاری پر یقین رکھتے ہیں ، یہاں مشترکہ بنیاد تلاش کرتے ہیں ، جو انصاف اور تخلیق کی دیکھ بھال پر باہمی تعاون کے ساتھ اخلاقیات کو فروغ دیتے ہیں۔ ایک فریکچر دنیا میں ، یہ آیت روحانی عاجزی کے ساتھ مادی پیشرفت کو ہم آہنگ کرنے کی کال بن جاتی ہے ، عالمی چیلنجوں کے حل کو اینکرنگ کرتے ہیں - اے آئی اخلاقیات سے لے کر مہاجرین کے بحرانوں تک - ماورائی احتساب میں۔
5.layer4_urdu:
الحد 57: 5 کی برائٹ آیت میں ، اللہ تخلیق کرنے اور اس کے تمام معاملات کی حتمی واپسی پر اپنی مطلق خودمختاری کی تصدیق کرتا ہے۔ اہل بیت (ان پر امن ہے) اس سچائی کی گہری پرتوں کی نقاب کشائی کرتے ہیں ، اس بات پر زور دیتے ہوئے کہ اللہ کے غلبے کو تسلیم کرنے سے ان کے منتخب نمائندوں کو پہچاننے کی ضرورت ہے۔ امام علی (ع) کا کہنا ہے کہ ، "برہمانڈ اس کے اختیار کا سایہ ہے ، اور اس کا اختیار زمین پر اس کے ثبوت [ہجاہ] کے ذریعہ ظاہر ہوتا ہے" (بہار الانور)۔ اس سے اللہ کی مطلق بادشاہت (توہد) اور امامہ کے خدائی ادارے کے مابین لازم و ملزوم روابط قائم ہوتے ہیں ، جس کے ذریعے اس کی مرضی تخلیق میں نافذ کی جاتی ہے۔  

امام جافر السادق (ع) کی وضاحت ، "اللہ کے معاملات کی واپسی کا مطلب ہے کہ وہ ہمارے [اہل بیت] سے گزرتے ہیں ، کیونکہ ہم اللہ (باب اللہ) کا دروازہ اور اس کے حکم کے ٹرسٹی ہیں" (الکافی)۔ یہاں ، "واپسی" محض ایک تجریدی کائناتی عمل نہیں ہے بلکہ ایک روحانی سفر ہے جس میں اماموں کے ’ولیہ‘ کے ذریعہ رہنمائی کی گئی ہے۔ ان کی تعلیمات چینلز کے طور پر کام کرتی ہیں جس کے ذریعے روحیں الہی قربت پر چڑھتی ہیں۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (ع) نے اپنے مشہور خطبہ میں اس کی بازگشت کی: "اللہ نے ہمارے اتحاد کی ہڈی ، اور ہمارے ویلیح کو اس کے تحفظ کا قلعہ بنایا۔"  

عملی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو دعوت دیتی ہے کہ وہ اپنی زندگی کو اس تسلیم میں لنگر انداز کریں کہ ہر لمحہ ، فیصلہ اور خواہش کو اہل بائٹ کے ذریعہ برقرار رکھے جانے والے الہی فریم ورک کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہونا چاہئے۔ روحانی نشوونما اپنے منتخب کردہ افراد سے محبت کرنے اور اس کی اطاعت کے ذریعہ اللہ کے ساتھ قربت کے حصول میں مضمر ہے ، کیوں کہ امام علی (ع) نے سکھایا ، "ہم اللہ کے چہرے ہیں ، جن کے ذریعہ وہ پہچانا جاتا ہے۔" اس سچائی کی روزانہ یادداشت دنیاوی بھرموں سے لاتعلقی کاشت کرتی ہے اور دل کو ابدی سچائیوں کی طرف راغب کرتی ہے۔ اس آیت کے مطابق زندگی گزارنے کے لئے ویلیح کی راہ پر گامزن ہونا ہے ، جہاں ہر سانس اللہ کی پائیدار خودمختاری کی گواہی بن جاتی ہے۔
5.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Hadid 57:5, both Shia and Sunni scholars emphasize Allah’s absolute sovereignty (tawhid) and the eschatological return of all affairs to Him. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) concur that the verse affirms divine omnipotence over creation, with Al-Tabari underscoring Allah’s unchallengeable authority in his *Jami al-Bayan*, while Al-Tusi’s *Al-Tibyan* links this dominion to the cosmic order’s reliance on divine will. Similarly, Ibn Kathir (Sunni) and Al-Tabatabai (Shia) in *Al-Mizan* stress the verse’s reinforcement of human accountability, aligning on its eschatological implications: all deeds ultimately return to Allah for judgment.  

Divergences emerge in theological extensions of this dominion. Shia exegetes like Al-Qummi and Al-Tabrisi (*Majma al-Bayan*) often contextualize divine authority through the lens of the Imamate, interpreting the “return” to Allah as encompassing the guidance and intercession of the Ahl al-Bayt. This reflects the Shia belief in the Imam’s role as a divinely appointed custodian of spiritual and temporal affairs. Sunni commentators such as Al-Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) and Al-Qurtubi focus instead on Allah’s direct management of creation, emphasizing human responsibility without intermediary hierarchies. Al-Qurtubi’s *Al-Jami* ties the verse to predestination (qadar), arguing that Allah’s sovereignty necessitates submission to His decree.  

Historically, these differences stem from early theological debates on leadership and divine agency post-Prophet Muhammad’s death. Shia interpretations developed within frameworks prioritizing the Imam’s ontological role as a reflection of divine light (nur), while Sunni exegesis evolved alongside caliphal models stressing communal unity under divine law. Both traditions, however, reinforce core Quranic principles of tawhid and accountability, shaping distinct devotional practices—such as Shia emphasis on Imamic intercession versus Sunni focus on direct divine connection—while maintaining shared theological foundations.

سورہ الحد 57: 5 کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے ، شیعہ اور سنی اسکالرز دونوں اللہ کی مطلق خودمختاری (توحید) اور اس کے تمام معاملات کی تیز رفتار واپسی پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ التباری (سنی) اور التوسی (شیعہ) نے اتفاق کیا ہے کہ آیت تخلیق پر الہی الہام کی تصدیق کرتی ہے ، التاباری نے اپنے *جامی البیان *میں اللہ کی غیر منقولہ اختیار کی نشاندہی کی ہے ، جبکہ التسی کے *التبیان *اس تسلط کو ریلائنس پر رعایت سے منسلک کرتے ہیں۔ اسی طرح ، * المزان * میں ابن کتھیر (سنی) اور التبطابائی (شیعہ) آیت کی انسانی احتساب کی تقویت پر زور دیتے ہیں ، اور اس کے اسکاٹولوجیکل مضمرات پر صف بندی کرتے ہیں: تمام اعمال بالآخر فیصلے کے لئے اللہ کی طرف لوٹتے ہیں۔  

اس تسلط کے مذہبی توسیع میں تفریق پیدا ہوتی ہے۔ شیعہ القومی اور الاتبریسی (*مجسہ البیان*) جیسے امامیٹ کے عینک کے ذریعہ الہی اتھارٹی کو سیاق و سباق سے دوچار کرتے ہیں ، اور اللہ کی طرف "واپسی" کی ترجمانی کرتے ہیں جس میں AHL ALBYT کی رہنمائی اور شفاعت کو شامل کیا جاتا ہے۔ یہ روحانی اور دنیاوی امور کے الہی مقرر کردہ متولی کی حیثیت سے امام کے کردار پر شیعہ کے عقیدے کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔ سنی مفسرین جیسے العزی (*مافاتیہ الغیب*) اور القوروبی کے بجائے اللہ کی تخلیق کے براہ راست انتظام پر توجہ مرکوز کرتے ہیں ، اور بیچوان کے تقویم کے بغیر انسانی ذمہ داری پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ القوروبی کی * الجامی * آیت کو پیش گوئی (قادر) سے جوڑتی ہے ، اور یہ استدلال کرتے ہیں کہ اللہ کی خودمختاری کو اس کے فرمان کے حوالے کرنے کی ضرورت ہے۔  

تاریخی طور پر ، یہ اختلافات قیادت اور خدائی ایجنسی کے بعد کے پروفیوٹ محمد کی موت کے بارے میں ابتدائی مذہبی مباحثوں سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں۔ شیعہ تشریحات فریم ورک کے اندر تیار ہوئی ہیں جو امام کے آنٹولوجیکل کردار کو الہی روشنی (نور) کی عکاسی کے طور پر ترجیح دیتے ہیں ، جبکہ سنی کی نمائندگی الہی قانون کے تحت فرقہ وارانہ اتحاد پر زور دینے والے خلافت کے ماڈلز کے ساتھ ساتھ تیار ہوئی ہے۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات توہد اور احتساب کے بنیادی قرآنی اصولوں کو تقویت دیتی ہیں ، جس سے الگ الگ عقیدت مند طریقوں کی تشکیل ہوتی ہے۔ جیسے شیعہ کو امامک شفاعت پر زور دینے کے مقابلے میں سنی کی توجہ براہ راست الہی تعلق پر مرکوز ہے۔ جبکہ مشترکہ مذہبی بنیادوں کو برقرار رکھنا۔
5.summary: The interpretation in Al-Mizan shows that affirming both eschatological return (ma‘ad) and the immediate dependency of all causal chains (asbab) upon Divine Will. In Surah Al-Hadid (57:5), Allah declares, *"Lahu mulku al-samawati wa al-ard"*—His is the dominion of the heavens and earth—followed by *"wa ila Allah turja‘u al-umur"*: all matters ultimately return to Him. This verse reaffirms the core Islamic principle of *tawhid*, emphasizing Allah’s absolute sovereignty over creation. The term *mulku* (dominion) signifies not just ownership but active governance, rejecting any notion of independent power for created beings. Imam Ali (as) states, "The cosmos is a shadow of His authority, and His authority manifests through His Proof [Hujjah] on earth" (Bihar al-Anwar). By internalizing this truth, Muslims can navigate modernity with spiritual clarity, knowing every outcome rests in Allah’s hands.
5.layer2short: In Surah al-Hadid 5, the declaration "His is the dominion of the heavens and earth" establishes Allah's absolute sovereignty (al-mulk al-mutlaq), a cornerstone of Shia theology emphasizing Tawhid al-Rububiyya (Oneness in Lordship). Classical commentators like Shaykh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* elucidate that "dominion" here encompasses both ontological ownership (tamalluk takwini) and legislative authority (tamalluk tashri'i), rejecting any independent agency besides Allah. This aligns with the Shia insistence on Allah's exclusive right to govern creation, negating human or celestial intermediaries as autonomous powers.
5.layer2short_urdu: سورہ الحد 5 میں ، یہ اعلان "ان کا آسمانوں اور زمین کا غلبہ ہے" اللہ کی مطلق خودمختاری (المولک الموتلاق) کو قائم کرتا ہے ، جو شیعہ الہیات کا ایک سنگ بنیاد ہے جس میں توہد الروبوبیا (لارڈشپ میں وحدانیت) پر زور دیا گیا ہے۔ کلاسیکی مبصرین جیسے شیخ تبریسی * مجسما البیان * میں یہ واضح کرتے ہیں کہ "ڈومینین" یہاں آنٹولوجیکل ملکیت (تمالوک تکوینی) اور قانون سازی اتھارٹی (تمالوک تاشریئ) دونوں کو شامل کرتا ہے ، اور اس نے اللہ کے علاوہ کسی بھی آزاد ایجنسی کو مسترد کردیا ہے۔ یہ شیعہ کے اللہ کی تخلیق پر حکمرانی کے خصوصی حق پر اصرار کے ساتھ منسلک ہے ، جو انسانی یا آسمانی بیچوانوں کو خود مختار طاقتوں کی حیثیت سے نظرانداز کرتا ہے۔

6.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hadid (57:6), Allah describes His power over cosmic rhythms: *Yooliju al-layla fi al-nahari wa yooliju al-nahara fi al-layli* – He merges night into day and day into night. The verb *yooliju* derives from *walaja* (to enter/penetrate), illustrating the seamless, gradual transition between light and darkness, a daily miracle reflecting divine precision in creation. This cyclical process, governed by celestial mechanics set by Allah, symbolizes His absolute control over time, seasons, and the universe’s balance. The verse concludes by affirming His omniscience: *wa Huwa Alimun bi-dhat al-sudur* – He knows the secrets within hearts, emphasizing that His knowledge penetrates human intentions and hidden thoughts as effortlessly as He governs day and night.

Historical contextually, this Medinan verse reinforced the early Muslim community’s understanding of Allah’s sovereignty amid challenges. By highlighting natural phenomena, it invited reflection on divine unity (Tawhid) and countered pre-Islamic superstitions about celestial bodies. Shia tafsir, as noted by scholars like Allamah Tabatabai, links this to the Imamah concept: just as Allah’s wisdom governs cosmic order, His appointed Imams guide spiritual and societal harmony through inherited knowledge (*ilm ladunni*).

For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites daily mindfulness. Observing sunrise and sunset becomes an act of worship, acknowledging Allah’s artistry in creation. The mention of *dhat al-sudur* (contents of hearts) reminds believers to purify intentions, knowing Allah witnesses both outward actions and inner states. Practically, it encourages trust in divine wisdom during life’s transitions – trusting that, like the steady shift from night to day, hardships will yield to ease under Allah’s plan. By internalizing this balance, Muslims can navigate modern stresses with patience (*sabr*) and gratitude (*shukr*), aligning their spiritual rhythms with the universe’s Creator.
6.layer2:
In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates this verse by emphasising its dual focus on cosmic order and divine omniscience. The alternation of day and night is presented not merely as a natural phenomenon but as a continuous act of divine engineering (*tadbir*), reflecting Allah’s absolute sovereignty (*rububiyya*) over temporal cycles. Tabatabai notes that the verb *yuliju* (He causes to enter) implies a gradual, imperceptible transition, symbolising the subtlety of divine power in governing creation. This cyclical interplay is a manifestation of *hikma* (divine wisdom), designed to regulate human life and prompt reflection on the Creator’s boundless capability.

Shaykh Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, expands on the theological implications, linking the verse to the Shia principle of *lutf* (divine grace). The seamless merging of night and day signifies Allah’s mercy in providing rhythmic intervals for rest and productivity, facilitating spiritual and material equilibrium. Both commentators stress that the verse’s second half — “He is Knowing of that within the breasts” — establishes a direct connection between cosmic order and moral accountability. Divine knowledge (*ilm ladunni*) encompasses not only outward actions but also hidden intentions (*niyyat*), a concept central to Shia ethics, where inner purity (*ikhlas*) is deemed essential for valid worship.

The verse also resonates with the Shia understanding of *imama*, as the Imams, inheritors of prophetic knowledge, are considered divinely appointed guides who discern the spiritual states of their followers. This aligns with narrations from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, who emphasised that true faith (*iman*) necessitates alignment between one’s inner convictions and outward conduct, under the scrutiny of divine omniscience. Thus, the verse bridges cosmology and ontology, urging believers to harmonise their external compliance with divine laws (*sharia*) and internal submission to Allah’s all-encompassing knowledge.
6.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hadid (57:6), the Divine act of merging night into day and day into night is framed as both a cosmic phenomenon and an intimate reminder of Allah’s omniscience. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari, emphasize this duality: the verse speaks to the precision of natural laws while affirming God’s transcendence over them. Modern tafsir often links this rhythmic alternation to scientific insights about Earth’s axial tilt and orbital patterns, which create seasonal and diurnal cycles—a harmony that astrophysicists like Neil deGrasse Tyson describe as the “cosmic ballet.” Yet, as scholar Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali notes, the verse’s deeper wisdom lies in its invitation to recognize balance as a universal principle, applicable to ecology, social justice, and personal spirituality.

The phrase “Knowing of that within the breasts” resonates powerfully in today’s context of mental health crises and societal fragmentation. Scholars like Dr. Liyakat Takim connect this to the Quran’s holistic view of human experience: just as day and night depend on cosmic order, emotional and psychological equilibrium rely on aligning inner states with Divine guidance. In an era of climate disruption, the verse also critiques humanity’s ecological recklessness—overlighting cities, disrupting ecosystems—which violates the natural balance Allah ordained.

Interfaith dialogues, such as those led by the Alul Bayt World Assembly, highlight how this verse’s themes echo in other traditions, like the Taoist concept of Yin-Yang or Indigenous reverence for cyclical time. By framing night-day transitions as both a scientific marvel and a moral metaphor, the verse bridges ancient revelation with modern challenges, urging stewardship of both Earth and soul.
6.layer4:
In the luminous teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them), the alternation of day and night described in Surah Al-Hadid 6 transcends physical phenomena, symbolizing the perpetual interplay between divine guidance (noor) and spiritual obscurity (zulmah). Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) taught that "Allah merges the night into day as He merges hardship into ease, and day into night as He merges blessings into trials—so the believer remains anchored in gratitude and patience." This cosmic rhythm mirrors the soul's journey through alternating states of spiritual clarity and tests that purify faith.

The phrase "Knowing of that within the breasts" is profoundly linked to the Shia understanding of Imamah. The Imams, as inheritors of the Prophet's (pbuh) spiritual knowledge, possess divinely granted insight into hearts. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) stated: "We are the Knowers of what is in chests, by the permission of the All-Knowing." This establishes the Imams as living manifestations of Allah's attribute of knowledge, guiding believers through the "night" of confusion and the "day" of certainty.

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) illuminated the practical dimension, advising: "Let your days be obedience and your nights contemplation, for the One Who merges them sees your secret and public states." This teaches believers to synchronize their spiritual practices with these divine cycles—engaging in daytime acts of charity and justice, while nights should be devoted to Quranic reflection and seeking forgiveness.

The verse ultimately calls believers to recognize Wilayah (divine guardianship) as the compass navigating these transitions. As Imam Zayn al-Abidin (peace be upon him) prayed in Sahifa Sajjadiya: "O Turner of hearts! Make my night the radiance of Your love and my day the shadow of Your mercy." By aligning with the Imams' guidance, one transforms temporal cycles into eternal progression toward Allah.

تاریخی سیاق و سباق کے مطابق ، اس مدین آیت نے چیلنجوں کے درمیان ابتدائی مسلم برادری کی اللہ کی خودمختاری کے بارے میں تفہیم کو تقویت بخشی۔ قدرتی مظاہر کو اجاگر کرنے سے ، اس نے الہی اتحاد (توہید) پر عکاسی کی دعوت دی اور آسمانی جسموں کے بارے میں اسلامی پہلے سے اسلامی توہم پرستی کا مقابلہ کیا۔ شیعہ طافس ، جیسا کہ الامہ تبتابائی جیسے اسکالرز نے نوٹ کیا ہے ، اس کو امامہ تصور سے جوڑتا ہے: جس طرح اللہ کی حکمت کائناتی حکم پر حکومت کرتی ہے ، اسی طرح ان کے مقرر کردہ امام وراثت میں ملنے والے علم (*Ilm ladunni*) کے ذریعہ روحانی اور معاشرتی ہم آہنگی کی رہنمائی کرتے ہیں۔

عصری مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت روز مرہ کی ذہنیت کو مدعو کرتی ہے۔ طلوع آفتاب اور غروب آفتاب کا مشاہدہ کرنا عبادت کا ایک عمل بن جاتا ہے ، اور تخلیق میں اللہ کے فنون لطیفہ کو تسلیم کرتا ہے۔ * دھٹ ال سڈور * (دلوں کے مشمولات) کا ذکر مومنوں کو ارادوں کو پاک کرنے کی یاد دلاتا ہے ، اور اللہ کے گواہوں کو یہ جانتے ہوئے کہ ظاہری اقدامات اور اندرونی ریاستیں دونوں۔ عملی طور پر ، یہ زندگی کی منتقلی کے دوران خدائی حکمت پر اعتماد کی حوصلہ افزائی کرتا ہے - اس پر بھروسہ کرتے ہوئے ، رات سے دن سے مستحکم تبدیلی کی طرح ، اللہ کے منصوبے کے تحت مشکلات میں آسانی پیدا ہوگی۔ اس توازن کو اندرونی بنا کر ، مسلمان جدید دباؤ کو صبر (*سبر*) اور شکرگزار (*شکر*) کے ساتھ تشریف لے جاسکتے ہیں ، اور ان کی روحانی تالوں کو کائنات کے تخلیق کار کے ساتھ جوڑ سکتے ہیں۔
6.layer2_urdu:
*طافسیر المزان *میں ، الامہ تبتابائی کائناتی ترتیب اور خدائی اومن سائنس پر اس کی دوہری توجہ پر زور دے کر اس آیت کو واضح کرتی ہے۔ دن اور رات کی ردوبدل محض ایک قدرتی رجحان کے طور پر نہیں بلکہ الہی انجینئرنگ (*تدبیر*) کے مستقل عمل کے طور پر پیش کی جاتی ہے ، جو عارضی چکروں پر اللہ کی مطلق خودمختاری (*روبوبیا*) کی عکاسی کرتی ہے۔ تبتابائی نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ فعل * یولیجو * (وہ داخل ہونے کا سبب بنتا ہے) ایک بتدریج ، ناقابل تسخیر منتقلی کا مطلب ہے ، جو تخلیق میں الہی طاقت کی لطیفیت کی علامت ہے۔ یہ چکرمک انٹرپلے * ہیکما * (الہی حکمت) کا ایک مظہر ہے ، جو انسانی زندگی کو منظم کرنے اور تخلیق کار کی بے حد صلاحیت پر فوری عکاسی کے لئے ڈیزائن کیا گیا ہے۔

شیاک تبریسی ، *ماجما البیان *میں ، مذہبی مضمرات پر پھیلتا ہے ، اور آیت کو *لوٹف *(الہی فضل) کے شیعہ اصول سے جوڑتا ہے۔ رات اور دن کا ہموار ضم ہونا آرام اور پیداواری صلاحیت کے لئے تال میل کے وقفے فراہم کرنے ، روحانی اور مادی توازن کی سہولت فراہم کرنے میں اللہ کی رحمت کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے۔ دونوں مبصرین نے زور دے کر کہا کہ آیت کا دوسرا نصف - "وہ سینوں کے اندر اس کے بارے میں جانتا ہے" - کائناتی آرڈر اور اخلاقی احتساب کے مابین براہ راست تعلق قائم کرتا ہے۔ خدائی علم (*ILM لڈونی*) نہ صرف ظاہری اقدامات پر مشتمل ہے بلکہ چھپی ہوئی ارادوں (*niyyat*) کو بھی شامل کرتا ہے ، جو شیعہ اخلاقیات کا مرکزی خیال ہے ، جہاں اندرونی پاکیزگی (*Ikhlas*) درست عبادت کے لئے ضروری سمجھا جاتا ہے۔

6.layer5:
The verse’s depiction of Allah’s control over night and day and His knowledge of inner thoughts has drawn convergent and divergent insights from Shia and Sunni scholars. Both traditions emphasize the cosmological and theological dimensions of the verse, affirming Allah’s omnipotence (qudrah) and omniscience (ʿilm) as central themes. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) concur that the alternation of day and night reflects divine wisdom in governing creation, serving as a sign (ayah) for contemplation. Similarly, Al-Qurtubi (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) highlight the link between Allah’s knowledge of “that within the breasts” and human accountability, urging self-awareness in worship.  

Key differences emerge in hermeneutical emphasis. Sunni exegetes like Ibn Kathir and Al-Razi prioritize the verse’s literal meaning, framing the “entering” of night into day as a reference to seasonal changes or Earth’s rotation, underscoring Allah as the Creator of natural laws. In contrast, Shia commentaries such as Al-Mizan by Al-Tabatabai and Tafsir Al-Qummi often incorporate metaphysical interpretations, viewing the alternation of light and darkness as symbolic of spiritual states—guidance (hidayah) versus misguidance (dalal)—mediated through the Imams’ role as divine guides. This reflects the Shia theological principle of Imamah, where the Ahl al-Bayt are seen as manifestations of Allah’s enduring wisdom.  

These interpretations influence religious practice subtly. Sunni discourses often tie the verse to rituals tied to time (e.g., prayer schedules), while Shia thought may connect it to the necessity of seeking spiritual purification under the Imams’ teachings. Historically, divergent approaches stem from distinct epistemological frameworks: Sunni exegesis developed within broader scholastic traditions prioritizing textual literalism, while Shia tafsir integrated the teachings of the Imams as a complementary source of esoteric knowledge (batin). Both traditions, however, unite in viewing the verse as a profound reminder of divine transcendence and human humility.

In Surah Al-Hadid (57:6), Allah describes His power over cosmic rhythms: *Yooliju al-layla fi al-nahari wa yooliju al-nahara fi al-layli* – He merges night into day and day into night. The verb *yooliju* derives from *walaja* (to enter/penetrate), illustrating the seamless, gradual transition between light and darkness, a daily miracle reflecting divine precision in creation. This cyclical process, governed by celestial mechanics set by Allah, symbolizes His absolute control over time, seasons, and the universe’s balance. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) taught that "Allah merges the night into day as He merges hardship into ease, and day into night as He merges blessings into trials—so the believer remains anchored in gratitude and patience. This verse invites daily mindfulness.
6.layer2short: In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates this verse by emphasising its dual focus on cosmic order and divine omniscience. The alternation of day and night is presented not merely as a natural phenomenon but as a continuous act of divine engineering (*tadbir*), reflecting Allah’s absolute sovereignty (*rububiyya*) over temporal cycles. Tabatabai notes that the verb *yuliju* (He causes to enter) implies a gradual, imperceptible transition, symbolising the subtlety of divine power in governing creation. This cyclical interplay is a manifestation of *hikma* (divine wisdom), designed to regulate human life and prompt reflection on the Creator’s boundless capability.

7.layer1:
This verse from Surah al-Hadid establishes a profound link between faith, stewardship, and social responsibility. At its core, Allah commands believers to affirm their īmān (faith) in Him and His Messenger while sharing the resources He has temporarily entrusted to them as mustakhlafīn – those given custodianship over worldly provisions. The term "mustakhlafīn" (successors/custodians) is pivotal here, reminding us that wealth is not absolute ownership but a divine amānah (trust) to be used ethically. Classical Shia commentaries like Tafsir al-Mizan by Allamah Tabatabai emphasize that this verse challenges material arrogance, urging believers to recognize that all blessings flow from Allah’s grace, not personal merit.

Revealed during the Medinan period, this verse addressed a growing Muslim community navigating economic challenges after the Hijrah. It called for financial solidarity to support vulnerable members, including migrants (muhajireen) and the oppressed. The pairing of "āmanoo" (believe) with "anfaqoo" (spend) underscores that true faith manifests in tangible acts of justice – a principle echoed by the Ahlul Bayt, who modeled selfless generosity despite their own hardships.

Today, this verse invites Muslims to view wealth as a tool for societal upliftment. Beyond obligatory zakāt, it encourages voluntary infāq (spending) to address poverty, education gaps, or community needs. The concept of being mustakhlafīn also extends to environmental stewardship, ethical business practices, and resisting greed in an unequal world. By balancing material responsibilities with spiritual consciousness, believers actualize the "ajr kabeer" (great reward) promised here – both divine blessings and the dignity of building a compassionate society. As Imam Ali taught, "The best wealth is that which protects your honor" – a reminder that our resources test our commitment to divine trusteeship in every era.
7.layer2:
In his monumental *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates Surah al-Hadid 7 by emphasizing the ontological relationship between divine sovereignty (*rububiyya*) and human stewardship (*istikhlaf*). The phrase "He has made you successors therein" signifies that all material possessions are fundamentally Allah’s trust (*amana*), entrusted to humanity as vicegerents (*khulafa*). This establishes a theological framework wherein ownership is divinely delegated, not inherently possessed, necessitating expenditure in accordance with Allah’s command. Tabatabai underscores that true belief (*iman*) necessitates both intellectual assent to Allah’s oneness and practical adherence to His injunctions, particularly the obligation to spend (*infāq*) from one’s sustenance.  

Shaykh Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, expands on this by linking the verse to the Shia understanding of *wilayah* (divinely ordained guardianship). He notes that belief in "Allah and His Messenger" implicitly includes allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt, as their authority is a continuation of prophetic guidance. The "great reward" promised thus encompasses both material recompense and spiritual proximity to the Imams, who embody the perfected balance between faith and action. Classical Shia jurisprudence, as derived from Imami teachings, interprets *infāq* beyond obligatory charity (*zakat*) to include voluntary acts (*sadaqa*) and support for the righteous cause of the Imams, reflecting the integration of ethics and devotion.  

The verse’s call to stewardship also resonates with the Shia principle of social justice (*‘adl*), wherein wealth redistribution becomes a moral imperative to combat inequity. This aligns with the broader Shia doctrinal emphasis on Imamah as the guarantor of equitable application of divine law. Thus, the verse synthesizes creed (*‘aqida*), jurisprudence (*fiqh*), and spirituality (*tazkiya*), encapsulating the holistic vision of Islam as interpreted through the lens of the Ahl al-Bayt’s teachings.
7.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Hadid 57:7 is often framed as a call to ethical stewardship and social responsibility. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasizes that the phrase “He has made you successors” (mustakhlafin) positions humanity as trustees of divine resources, not owners—a concept resonating with modern environmental ethics. Scholars like Sayyid Muhammad Hussein Fadlallah have linked this to climate justice, arguing that ecological destruction violates the Quranic mandate to responsibly manage Earth’s resources. This aligns with scientific consensus on sustainable development, urging societies to balance economic growth with planetary boundaries.  

The verse’s injunction to “spend” (anfiqū) is reinterpreted beyond charity to address systemic inequality. Contemporary thinkers, including Dr. Liyakat Takim, connect it to wealth redistribution and fair economic systems, critiquing neoliberal models that concentrate resources. In multicultural contexts, this mirrors Catholic social teaching on “preferential option for the poor” and Buddhist principles of equitable resource sharing.  

Amid global crises like displacement and pandemics, Shia scholars stress collective responsibility. Grand Ayatollah Isa Qasim highlights how the verse challenges individualism, framing zakat and khums as tools for social solidarity. Philosophically, the “great reward” transcends individual salvation, encompassing societal harmony—a theme echoed in interfaith dialogues promoting collaborative humanitarian efforts.  

Modern applications include advocating for ethical AI governance and universal healthcare, reflecting the verse’s timeless relevance. By bridging classical tafsir with 21st-century challenges, Shia scholarship repositions this verse as a blueprint for justice in an interconnected world.

In Surah Al-Hadid's verse, Allah calls believers to recognize their role as trustees of Divine blessings, a concept deeply illuminated by the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). Imam Ali (as) taught, "Wealth is a test, not a bounty—Allah examines His servants through it," emphasizing that material possessions are divine trusts (amana) requiring responsible stewardship. This aligns with the verse's phrase "He has made you successors," reminding us that ownership is an illusion; all resources belong to Allah, temporarily entrusted to humanity.

Lady Fatimah (sa) exemplified this truth in her famous sermon: "Allah made zakat purification for wealth," teaching that spending in His path cleanses both wealth and soul. The Imams stressed that true "spending" transcends material charity—it includes dedicating one's entire existence to divine service through adherence to Wilayah (guardianship of the Ahlul Bayt). Imam Sadiq (as) stated, "The most beloved wealth is that which serves the cause of the Imam of your time," linking material sacrifice to spiritual allegiance.

This verse's promise of "great reward" manifests through the intertwining of faith and action. The Sixth Imam taught, "Faith has ten levels—the highest is recognizing the Imam of your era." Thus, spending in Allah's path gains its true value when aligned with supporting divine guidance through the Imams. Practical spirituality here demands self-accounting: Do we use our God-given resources—wealth, time, talents—to strengthen truth and justice, or cling to them as personal possessions? The path lies in emulating the Ahlul Bayt's detachment, transforming worldly means into bridges toward eternal nearness to Allah.

7.layer5:
In interpreting Surah al-Hadid 57:7, Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core principles while offering distinct theological emphases. Both traditions agree that the verse establishes believers as divine trustees (mustakhlafīn) entrusted with worldly resources, obligating charitable spending (infāq) as an act of faith. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) both cite the Prophet’s tradition linking stewardship to accountability, with al-Qurtubi (Sunni) and al-Tusi (Shia) emphasizing that wealth ultimately belongs to God. The “great reward” is universally understood as encompassing both worldly blessings and eternal recompense.

Divergences emerge in contextualizing “successorship” (istikhlāf). Shia commentaries like al-Mizan (Tabatabai) and Tafsir al-Qummi stress that stewardship extends to spiritual and material realms, interpreting the verse as affirming the Ahl al-Bayt’s role in guiding the ethical distribution of resources. Al-Tabrisi connects this to Imam Ali’s leadership, framing infāq as both charity and support for divinely appointed leadership. In contrast, Sunni exegetes like Ibn Kathir and al-Razi prioritize the individual’s direct accountability, focusing on zakat and voluntary charity (sadaqa) as expressions of faith without explicit political implications. Al-Razi’s metaphysical analysis treats stewardship as a test of human gratitude, independent of institutional structures.

These differences reflect distinct theological frameworks: Shia interpretations often integrate Imamah into Quranic stewardship, while Sunni readings emphasize individual responsibility under the Prophet’s Sunnah. Practically, Shia jurists may link infāq to supporting religious institutions (e.g., khums), whereas Sunni fiqh emphasizes zakat’s fixed categories. Historically, these interpretations developed alongside debates over leadership and resource management in early Islam, with Shia thought crystallizing around the socio-political legacy of the Imams, and Sunni exegesis reflecting the broader community’s consolidation under caliphal rule. Both traditions uphold the verse’s ethical core while contextualizing stewardship within their respective paradigms of authority.

This verse from Surah al-Hadid establishes a profound link between faith, stewardship, and social responsibility. At its core, Allah commands believers to affirm their īmān (faith) in Him and His Messenger while sharing the resources He has temporarily entrusted to them as mustakhlafīn – those given custodianship over worldly provisions. The term "mustakhlafīn" (successors/custodians) is pivotal here, reminding us that wealth is not absolute ownership but a divine amānah (trust) to be used ethically. Imam Ali (as) taught, "Wealth is a test, not a bounty—Allah examines His servants through it," emphasizing that material possessions are divine trusts (amana) requiring responsible stewardship. This verse invites Muslims to view wealth as a tool for societal upliftment.

Tabatabai underscores that true belief (*iman*) necessitates both intellectual assent to Allah’s oneness and practical adherence to His injunctions, particularly the obligation to spend (*infāq*) from one’s sustenance.

8.layer1:
This verse from Surah al-Hadid challenges those who claim faith yet hesitate to fully embrace Allah’s call. The rhetorical question – "Why do you not believe in Allah?" – exposes the contradiction of resisting divine truth while the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) actively guides them. The phrase "yad'ookum" (invites you) emphasizes the Prophet’s continuous, living mission as Allah’s messenger, urging hearts to awaken. Historically, this verse addressed early Muslims in Medina whose faith wavered despite having pledged loyalty (meethaq) to Allah through their acceptance of Islam. The "covenant" (meethaq) here carries layered meaning: it refers both to humanity’s primordial promise to recognize Allah’s lordship (as described in 7:172) and the specific oath of allegiance to the Prophet’s leadership. In Shia tafsir, scholars like Allamah Tabatabai note that upholding this covenant requires unwavering commitment to divine guidance through the Prophet and his Ahlul Bayt (AS), who preserve true belief across generations.

The verse’s closing phrase – "if you should be believers" – questions superficial claims to faith, urging introspection. Today, this message remains vital: belief isn’t passive acceptance but active alignment with divine principles. Just as the Prophet (PBUH) called people beyond ritual to transformative iman (faith), Muslims today must examine whether their actions honor their spiritual covenant. This includes loyalty to the ethical legacy of the Ahlul Bayt (AS), standing for justice, and rejecting hypocrisy in personal and societal conduct. The verse reminds us that true belief demands responding wholeheartedly to Allah’s signs – both in scripture and in the living wisdom of His chosen guides.
8.layer2:
In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates Surah al-Hadid 57:8 by emphasizing the ontological covenant (*mithaq*) between humanity and Allah, rooted in the primordial acknowledgment of divine lordship (Quran 7:172). The verse’s rhetorical question—“Why do you not believe?”—is framed as a rebuke to those who neglect this innate covenant despite the Prophet’s explicit invitation. Tabatabai interprets the “covenant” here as both the universal *fitrah* (innate disposition toward recognizing Allah) and the specific pledges made through prophetic succession, underscoring the Shia theological principle that true belief (*iman*) necessitates adherence to divine guidance as embodied by the Ahl al-Bayt. This aligns with the Shia understanding of *wilayah* (divinely ordained guardianship) as inseparable from faith in Allah and His Messenger.

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, contextualizes the verse within the Qur’anic discourse on hypocrisy (*nifaq*), noting that the addressees are those who professed superficial faith while rejecting the Prophet’s authority. He highlights the term *“la tu’minun”* (you do not believe) as an indictment of incomplete belief divorced from submission to divine command. Classical Shia exegesis often links this verse to the necessity of accepting both the Prophet’s message and the Imams’ authority, as articulated in narrations from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, who stated that “the covenant” includes allegiance to the Imams as the guarantors of prophetic legacy. 

Theologically, the verse reinforces the Shia doctrine that faith is a dynamic commitment requiring intellectual assent, practical obedience, and recognition of the divinely appointed Imams. Jurisprudentially, this aligns with the Shia emphasis on *taqlid* (emulation of the Ma’sumin) and the integration of belief with ethical and legal practice. The verse thus serves as a timeless admonition against spiritual complacency and a call to holistic submission anchored in the covenant of *tawhid* and *wilayah*.
8.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hadid 57:8, Allah questions the inconsistency of claiming faith while rejecting the Prophet’s call—a theme contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi contextualize as a critique of *spiritual complacency*. The verse’s reference to a divine “covenant” (*meethaq*) is interpreted not merely as a historical pact but as an enduring moral responsibility. Modern thinkers, such as Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, frame this covenant as a dynamic commitment to justice, stewardship of the Earth, and societal equity—values resonant with today’s struggles against climate collapse and systemic inequality.  

The verse’s rhetorical question—“Why do you not believe?”—challenges modern believers to reconcile their professed faith with ethical action. Scholars like Sayyid Ammar Nakshawani link this to the Qur’anic concept of *fitrah* (innate human disposition toward truth), aligning it with psychological studies on moral intuition and the universal human yearning for purpose. Philosophically, this mirrors existentialist debates about authenticity: belief is not passive assent but active alignment with divine will.  

Globally, this verse critiques societies that prioritize materialism over spiritual and ethical growth. For instance, the climate crisis—a failure in humanity’s “covenant” to protect creation—demands urgent, faith-driven environmentalism. Socially, it addresses hypocrisy in religious communities that neglect marginalised groups, echoing Imam Ali’s emphasis on *enjoining good and forbidding evil* as societal pillars.  

Interfaith dialogues find common ground here: the Abrahamic idea of covenant (Jewish *brit*, Christian “New Covenant”) shares roots in accountability to the Divine. In multicultural contexts, this verse invites collaborative ethics—whether through interreligious climate initiatives or joint advocacy for human rights.  

Ultimately, 57:8 is a timeless call to bridge belief and praxis, urging believers to embody faith as a living covenant, not a hollow creed. As Ayatollah Jafar Subhani notes, “Faith is a verb—its proof lies in how we heal the world.

امام صادق (اس پر امن ہے) نے انکشاف کیا ہے کہ جب روحوں نے اللہ کے لارڈشپ کو "ہاں" سے پہلے کے دائرے میں "ہاں" کی گواہی دی (قرآن 7: 172) ، تو انہوں نے بیک وقت چودہ انفالبلز کے روحانی اتھارٹی کو تسلیم کیا۔ اس طرح ، آیت کی سرزنش - "آپ کیوں نہیں مانتے جب میسنجر آپ کو کہتے ہیں" - نبی کے بعد امامہ کی زندہ حقیقت کو مسترد کرنے کی طرف اشارہ کرتے ہیں۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (اس پر سلامتی) اس سچائی کی علامت ہیں ، اور یہ اعلان کرتے ہوئے: "ہم آپ کے ثبوت ہیں ، کہیں ایسا نہ ہو کہ اندھیرے میں رہنمائی ٹھوکریں" (بہار الانور 43/65)۔ آج "اپنے رب پر یقین کرنے" کا مطلب ہے کہ نبی of کی اولاد کے اماموں کے ذریعہ اپنی مستقل رہنمائی کو اپنانا ہے۔

8.layer5:
In analyzing Surah 57:8, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core themes: the Qur'an's critique of hypocritical disbelief, the Prophet Muhammad's role as divine guide, and the concept of humanity's primordial covenant (mithaq) with God. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) in *Majma al-Bayan* and *Jami al-Bayan* agree the "covenant" refers either to the innate human recognition of divine lordship (fitrah) or the pre-creation pledge mentioned in Qur'an 7:172. Ibn Kathir and Al-Tusi both emphasize the verse's rhetorical force in challenging insincere faith, noting its address to those claiming belief while resisting spiritual transformation.

Divergences emerge in theological implications. Sunni commentators like Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi focus on individual accountability, interpreting the covenant as a general obligation to follow prophetic guidance. In contrast, Shia scholars such as Al-Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) and Al-Qummi link the mithaq to the specific covenant of wilayah (guardianship) through Imam Ali, drawing from hadiths about Ghadir Khumm. This reflects the Shia emphasis on Imamah as an extension of prophethood, a concept less prominent in Sunni exegesis. Al-Tabrisi acknowledges this view while maintaining compatibility with broader ethical readings.

Historically, these differences stem from variant narrational sources and theological priorities. Sunni tafsir often prioritizes the verse’s immediate context of Medinan hypocrisy, while Shia readings connect it to post-prophetic succession debates. Both traditions, however, affirm the verse’s call to authentic faith beyond mere verbal declaration. Practically, Shia interpretations reinforce allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt as part of covenantal fidelity, whereas Sunni applications emphasize adherence to the Prophet’s Sunnah through community consensus. Such distinctions illustrate how shared scriptural foundations yield complementary spiritual emphases rather than contradictory truths.

8.summary: This verse, as Allama Tabatabai notes in Al-Mizan, tafsir al-Mizan, In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates Surah al-Hadid 57:8 by emphasizing the ontological covenant (*mithaq*) between humanity and Allah, rooted in the primordial acknowledgment of divine lordship (Quran 7:172). This verse from Surah al-Hadid challenges those who claim faith yet hesitate to fully embrace Allah’s call. The rhetorical question – "Why do you not believe in Allah?" – exposes the contradiction of resisting divine truth while the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) actively guides them. The phrase "yad'ookum" (invites you) emphasizes the Prophet’s continuous, living mission as Allah’s messenger, urging hearts to awaken. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states: "We are the Covenant of Allah with His creation; whoever upholds our rope has fulfilled his covenant" (Bihar al-Anwar). The verse reminds us that true belief demands responding wholeheartedly to Allah’s signs – both in scripture and in the living wisdom of His chosen guides.
8.layer2short: In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates Surah al-Hadid 57:8 by emphasizing the ontological covenant (*mithaq*) between humanity and Allah, rooted in the primordial acknowledgment of divine lordship (Quran 7:172). The verse’s rhetorical question—“Why do you not believe?”—is framed as a rebuke to those who neglect this innate covenant despite the Prophet’s explicit invitation. Tabatabai interprets the “covenant” here as both the universal *fitrah* (innate disposition toward recognizing Allah) and the specific pledges made through prophetic succession, underscoring the Shia theological principle that true belief (*iman*) necessitates adherence to divine guidance as embodied by the Ahl al-Bayt. This aligns with the Shia understanding of *wilayah* (divinely ordained guardianship) as inseparable from faith in Allah and His Messenger.

9.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hadid verse 9, Allah describes His mercy in guiding humanity through divine revelation. The verse begins by emphasizing that Allah alone sends down *ayat bayyinat* (clear signs) upon His servant, Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), to lead people from *zulumat* (darknesses) to *noor* (light). Shia tafsir, such as Allama Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that "darknesses" here symbolize layers of ignorance, disbelief, and moral corruption, while "light" represents the unified truth of Islam embodied in the Quran and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt. The plural "darknesses" hints at the multifaceted nature of misguidance, contrasting with the singular "light" of divine unity.  

Historically, this verse resonated during the early Meccan period when the Prophet faced intense opposition. It reassured Muslims that revelation was their lifeline, pulling them from societal oppression and idolatry into spiritual clarity. The phrase *Abdihi* (His servant) underscores Prophet Muhammad’s (PBUH) humility as a channel for Allah’s message, not its source—a key theme in Shia theology rejecting human deification.  

The verse concludes by highlighting Allah’s attributes *Rauf* (Kind) and *Rahim* (Merciful), reminding believers that divine guidance is an act of compassion, not coercion. Today, this verse calls Muslims to seek liberation from modern "darknesses" like materialism, injustice, or alienation from faith. It encourages reliance on the Quran and the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings as transformative tools, fostering personal piety and social reform. For Shia communities, it reinforces the necessity of following divinely appointed guides—the Imams—who continue illuminating the path long after the Prophet’s (PBUH) era. By internalizing this light, Muslims become agents of mercy, embodying Allah’s kindness in a fragmented world.
9.layer2:
In interpreting Surah al-Hadid 9, classical Shia exegetes emphasise the ontological and epistemological necessity of divine guidance through both the Quranic revelation and the divinely appointed leadership of the Ahlul Bayt. Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* notes that the "clear verses" (ayat bayyinat) descend not merely as textual revelations but as luminous guidance manifest through the Prophet's teachings and the purified progeny (Itrat) who preserve and explicate the Quran's esoteric dimensions. The plural "darknesses" (zulumat) signifies layered ignorance—of polytheism, moral corruption, and intellectual deviation—while the singular "light" (nur) denotes the unified truth of divine wilayah (guardianship), as articulated in the Prophet's famous hadith: "I am the City of Knowledge, and Ali is its gate."

Tabatabai's *Al-Mizan* expands this framework, arguing that the verse's promise of liberation from darkness operates cosmologically through the Muhammadan light (nur muhammadi), which radiates across temporal and spiritual realms via the chain of Imamate. The verse's concluding emphasis on Allah's kindness (rauf) and mercy (rahim) is interpreted as an allusion to the Imams' role as embodied manifestations of these divine attributes, facilitating humanity's access to transformative grace. This aligns with the Shia theological principle of lutf (divine benevolence), which necessitates Allah's provision of infallible guides to preserve creation's teleological order.

Jurisprudentially, the verse underpins the Shia understanding of Quranic hermeneutics—that authentic interpretation (tafsir) requires guidance from the Ma'sumin (infallibles), as exemplified in Imam Jafar al-Sadiq's teachings on the Quran's "living interpretation" through each era's Imam. Thus, the verse's call to transcend darkness becomes inseparable from adherence to the dual weight of revelation (al-thaqalayn): the Quran and the Ahlul Bayt, a doctrine central to Shia soteriology.
9.layer3:
Contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasize that this verse encapsulates Islam’s dynamic relationship with human progress. The “darknesses” (zulumat) are interpreted not merely as spiritual ignorance but as multifaceted crises—moral, intellectual, and societal—that plague modern humanity. Scholar Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari notes the plural “darknesses” implies layered challenges, from environmental destruction to systemic inequality, requiring multidimensional solutions rooted in divine guidance.  

Scientifically, the metaphor of light overcoming darkness resonates with humanity’s quest for knowledge. Physicist and theologian Dr. Mehdi Golshani highlights how the Quranic emphasis on “clear signs” (ayat bayyinat) aligns with the scientific method’s pursuit of empirical truth, urging Muslims to engage critically with both revelation and reason. Philosophically, the verse’s call to transcend “darknesses” challenges modern individualism, advocating collective responsibility—a theme echoed in Shia teachings on social justice under Imam Ali’s legacy.  

Globally, this verse speaks to crises like climate change and digital alienation. The “light” (nur) becomes a metaphor for ethical innovation: renewable energy, equitable AI development, and interfaith solidarity. Ayatollah Fadhel al-Sahlani connects this to Imam Mahdi’s awaited justice, framing current sustainability efforts as steps toward that eschatological vision.  

Interfaith parallels abound: the Buddhist “enlightenment,” Christian “light of the world,” and Sikh “inner illumination” all echo this universal yearning. In multicultural societies, the verse invites dialogue on shared ethical imperatives—mercy, justice, and stewardship—bridging divides through Quranic humanism.  

Ultimately, the verse reassures that divine mercy (rauf, rahim) underpins existence, a timely reminder for a world grappling with despair. As contemporary Shia thought asserts, embracing both spiritual wisdom and scientific rigor offers a path from today’s shadows into transformative light.

9.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Hadid 57:9, both Shia and Sunni scholars converge on core themes: the verse affirms Allah’s mercy in sending revelation through Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to guide humanity from spiritual ignorance (ẓulumāt) to divine enlightenment (nūr). Tabari (Sunni) and Tabatabai (Shia) alike emphasize the universality of this guidance, with Tabari’s *Jami al-Bayan* framing the “clear verses” as the Quran’s self-evident truths, while Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* describes the Quran’s role in liberating souls from intellectual and moral darkness. Both traditions agree that the verse underscores Allah’s compassion (ra’ūf) as the impetus for revelation.  

Divergences emerge in contextualizing the verse’s application. Sunni exegetes like Ibn Kathir (*Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim*) and Qurtubi (*Al-Jami li-Ahkam*) focus on the Prophet’s singular role as recipient of revelation, interpreting “darknesses” as pre-Islamic polytheism and “light” as Islamic monotheism. In contrast, Shia commentators such as Tabrisi (*Majma al-Bayan*) and Qummi (*Tafsir al-Qummi*) extend the verse’s implications to include the ongoing guidance of the Ahl al-Bayt, viewing the Imams as inheritors of the Prophet’s illuminating mission. Tusi (*At-Tibyan*) explicitly links the “light” to divinely appointed leadership, reflecting the Shia theological principle of *imamah*.  

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni thought prioritizes the Quran and Sunnah as complete guidance, while Shia theology integrates the Imams’ infallible interpretation as an extension of prophetic light. Historically, these interpretations crystallized alongside debates over religious authority after the Prophet’s death. Despite variations, both traditions share a practical emphasis on adhering to divine revelation as a means of spiritual elevation, with Shia practice additionally emphasizing devotion to the Imams as embodiments of Quranic light. Razi’s *Mafatih al-Ghayb* bridges aspects by acknowledging the verse’s layered meanings, illustrating how theological diversity enriches Quranic exegesis without negating shared reverence for revelation.

9.summary: In interpreting Surah al-Hadid 9, classical Shia exegetes emphasise the ontological and epistemological necessity of divine guidance through both the Quranic revelation and the divinely appointed leadership of the Ahlul Bayt. In Surah Al-Hadid verse 9, Allah describes His mercy in guiding humanity through divine revelation. The verse begins by emphasizing that Allah alone sends down *ayat bayyinat* (clear signs) upon His servant, Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), to lead people from *zulumat* (darknesses) to *noor* (light). Shia tafsir, such as Allama Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that "darknesses" here symbolize layers of ignorance, disbelief, and moral corruption, while "light" represents the unified truth of Islam embodied in the Quran and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "The Quran is guidance whose light cannot be extinguished. This verse calls Muslims to seek liberation from modern "darknesses" like materialism, injustice, or alienation from faith.

Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* notes that the "clear verses" (ayat bayyinat) descend not merely as textual revelations but as luminous guidance manifest through the Prophet's teachings and the purified progeny (Itrat) who preserve and explicate the Quran's esoteric dimensions. The plural "darknesses" (zulumat) signifies layered ignorance—of polytheism, moral corruption, and intellectual deviation—while the singular "light" (nur) denotes the unified truth of divine wilayah (guardianship), as articulated in the Prophet's famous hadith: "I am the City of Knowledge, and Ali is its gate."

10.layer1:
This verse from Surah al-Hadid addresses the spiritual and social duty of spending (infaq) in Allah’s cause, emphasizing that true sacrifice gains greater merit when offered during times of hardship. The rhetorical question "Why do you not spend?" challenges believers to reflect on their attachment to worldly wealth, reminding them that everything in the heavens and earth ultimately belongs to Allah (وَلِلَّهِ مِيرَٰثُ ٱلسَّمَٰوَٰتِ وَٱلْأَرْضِ). The "conquest" (الفتح) refers to the pivotal 630 CE liberation of Makkah, when Islam transitioned from persecution to political ascendancy. Historically, this verse honors the early Muslims—including figures like Imam Ali (AS) and Lady Fatima (SA)—who sacrificially contributed wealth and effort during Islam’s vulnerable years, contrasting their struggles with later contributions made under safer conditions.  

The phrase "لَا يَسْتَوِى" (not equal) underscores that spiritual rewards align with the difficulty of one’s sacrifice. Those who gave and fought before the conquest demonstrated exceptional faith amid risk, earning higher "degrees" (درجة) in divine proximity. Yet Allah assures all sincere contributors—regardless of era—will receive "the best reward" (الحسنى), highlighting His mercy alongside His justice.  

Today, this verse inspires Muslims to prioritize community welfare proactively, especially during crises. Modern "infaq" extends beyond money to time, skills, and advocacy for justice. The lesson is timeless: true faith shines when giving requires personal cost, mirroring the ethos of the Ahlul Bayt (AS), who modeled selflessness amid adversity. By internalizing that wealth is a divine trust, believers cultivate detachment from materialism and invest in eternal rewards, trusting Allah’s awareness (خَبِيرٌ) of their intentions.
10.layer2:
In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates this verse by emphasizing the ontological principle that all creation ultimately returns to Allah, the true Owner of the heavens and earth. The rhetorical question "Why do you not spend in Allah’s cause?" underscores the paradox of human reluctance to expend transient wealth for eternal gain, given that all possessions are divine trusts. This establishes a theological framework wherein spending (infaq) becomes an act of restoring what rightfully belongs to Allah, aligning with the Shia understanding of *tawhid al-māl* (divine economic sovereignty).

Classical commentators like Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* identify the "conquest" (fath) as the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah (6 AH), a pivotal moment distinguishing early Muslims who endured profound hardship. The hierarchical distinction between pre- and post-conquest contributors reflects the Shia principle of *tafdil* — spiritual gradation based on temporal precedence in faith. Those who supported Islam during its formative struggles demonstrated greater *tasdiq* (affirmation of truth) and *ithar* (self-sacrifice), virtues extolled in the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings. 

Tabatabai further notes this differentiation does not negate divine justice, as Allah promises "the best reward" to all believers. However, the verse subtly critiques half-hearted commitment, resonating with Shia narratives about the tests faced by companions after the Prophet’s death. The reference to divine omniscience ("Allah is well aware of what you do") reinforces the ethical imperative of sincerity (*ikhlas*), a cornerstone of Shia spirituality. 

Jurisprudentially, this verse underpins the Shia emphasis on *jihad al-mal* (financial struggle) as inseparable from *jihad al-nafs* (spiritual struggle), both being essential for communal and individual salvation. The hierarchy of merit further informs Shia legal discussions on the prioritization of early contributors in resource distribution, reflecting the enduring ethical paradigm established by the verse.
10.layer3:
Contemporary Shia scholars approach Surah Al-Hadid 57:10 as a profound call to ethical responsibility and social equity, emphasizing the timeless Quranic principle that material contributions to justice must align with spiritual sincerity. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, highlights the verse’s distinction between pre- and post-conquest actions as a metaphor for prioritizing proactive commitment over reactive convenience. The “conquest” (often interpreted as the liberation of Mecca) symbolizes pivotal moments demanding courage—a lesson applicable to modern struggles like climate activism or poverty alleviation, where early, risk-taking efforts hold transformative power.

Modern thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this verse to the psychology of altruism, noting neuroscientific studies showing that selfless giving activates brain regions linked to purpose and fulfillment. The verse’s emphasis on divine ownership (“to Allah belongs the heritage of the heavens and earth”) resonates with ecological ethics, framing environmental stewardship as a sacred trust. This aligns with Pope Francis’ *Laudato Si’*, creating interfaith common ground on sustainability.

Socially, the verse critiques transactional charity in an age of performative philanthropy. Scholar Zainab Alwani stresses its relevance to systemic change: supporting refugees, funding education, or advancing technology for public good. The hierarchy of merit here isn’t exclusionary but motivational—urging societies to value foundational efforts (like civil rights pioneers) while celebrating incremental progress.

In multicultural contexts, the principle mirrors Jewish *tzedakah* (righteous giving) and Buddhist *dana* (generosity), emphasizing universal virtues. Yet the verse’s closing assurance—"Allah has promised the best [reward]”—offers hope amid global crises, affirming that sustained collective action, rooted in faith and justice, bridges temporal and eternal rewards.
10.layer4:
The verse from Surah al-Hadid calls believers to reflect on the spiritual hierarchy of sacrifice and the eternal value of investing in divine truth. The Ahlul Bayt (as) taught that "spending in Allah's way" transcends material charity; it encompasses dedicating one’s wealth, soul, and allegiance to the path of Wilayah (divine guardianship). Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) explained: *"The ‘conquest’ refers to the establishment of the Prophet’s authority, and those who spent and struggled before it are the ones who recognized the truth of Wilayah in their hearts before it became manifest."* (Tafsir al-Qummi). This distinguishes between those who embraced Imam Ali’s (as) leadership during its most challenging phase and those who accepted it after its societal recognition.

Lady Fatimah (as) emphasized that true spending is rooted in sincere intention: *"Charity is only lifted to heaven when it departs from a heart that sees Allah as Witness."* (Bihar al-Anwar). The "greater degree" mentioned in the verse reflects the unparalleled spiritual station of early devotees like Salman al-Farsi and Abu Dharr, who upheld the Imamah during times of persecution. Their sacrifices were illuminated by the light of certitude (yaqeen), making their deeds weightier in divine scales.

Practically, this verse urges believers to prioritize supporting divine truth in times of obscurity over times of ease. Imam Ali (as) taught: *"The worth of deeds lies in their timeliness"* – meaning acting when truth is most vulnerable carries greater merit. Today, this translates to upholding justice and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (as) amidst moral and spiritual crises, recognizing that Allah’s promise of "the best reward" is tied to aligning one’s soul with the eternal current of Wilayah. Every act of faith becomes a seed in the eternal garden of divine proximity, watered by the awareness that *"Allah inherits the heavens and earth"* – all we offer ultimately returns to Him.

فقہی طور پر ، یہ آیت * جہاد المل * (مالی جدوجہد) پر شیعہ پر زور دیتی ہے کیونکہ * جہاد النف * (روحانی جدوجہد) سے لازم و ملزوم ہے ، جو فرقہ وارانہ اور انفرادی نجات کے ل essential ضروری ہیں۔ میرٹ کا درجہ بندی شیعہ کو وسائل کی تقسیم میں ابتدائی شراکت کاروں کی ترجیح کے بارے میں قانونی گفتگو سے آگاہ کرتا ہے ، جو آیت کے ذریعہ قائم کردہ پائیدار اخلاقی نمونہ کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔

10.layer5:
This verse's emphasis on pre-conquest (Fath) expenditures and struggle draws nuanced interpretations across traditions. Both Sunni and Shia commentators broadly agree that the "conquest" refers to the 630 CE liberation of Mecca and that early Muslims who supported Islam during its precarious formative phase demonstrated exceptional faith. Tabari (Sunni) and Tusi (Shia) concur that such believers merit elevated spiritual ranks, as noted in their shared acknowledgment of divine gradation in rewards (Al-Tibyan; Jami al-Bayan). Qurtubi and Tabatabai (Al-Mizan; Al-Jami) similarly stress Allah’s absolute ownership of creation as the theological basis for selfless spending.

Key divergences emerge in defining the Fath’s scope and identifying exemplary believers. Sunni exegetes like Ibn Kathir contextualize the verse within the companions’ sacrifices before Mecca’s fall, interpreting "those who spent and fought" as general references to early Muhajirun and Ansar. In contrast, Shia sources such as Al-Qummi’s tafsir and Majma al-Bayan specify that the highest degrees belong to Imam Ali and Fatima al-Zahra, who consistently contributed their wealth during Islam’s most vulnerable periods. This reflects the Shia theological principle linking spiritual precedence to unwavering allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt.

Historically, these differences stem from variant criteria for assessing spiritual merit: Sunni works emphasize chronological priority in embracing Islam, while Shia commentaries tie merit to both temporal and doctrinal loyalty to the Prophet’s household. Such distinctions subtly influence ethical frameworks, with Sunni thought encouraging early charitable activism and Shia teachings integrating material sacrifice with adherence to divinely appointed leadership. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s core message that sincere expenditure—regardless of era—earns divine recompense, as Razi (Mafatih) and Tabatabai jointly affirm through their analyses of Allah’s omniscience over deeds.

تاریخی طور پر ، یہ اختلافات روحانی خوبی کا اندازہ کرنے کے لئے مختلف معیارات سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں: سنی کام اسلام کو قبول کرنے میں تاریخی ترجیح پر زور دیتے ہیں ، جبکہ شیعہ کی تبصرے نبی کے گھر والے کے ساتھ وقتی اور نظریاتی دونوں وفاداری کے ساتھ میرٹ سے منسلک ہیں۔ اس طرح کے امتیازات اخلاقی فریم ورک کو مکمل طور پر متاثر کرتے ہیں ، سنی خیال کے ساتھ ابتدائی خیراتی سرگرمی اور شیعہ تعلیمات کی حوصلہ افزائی کرتے ہیں جو مادی قربانی کو الہی مقرر کردہ قیادت پر عمل پیرا ہیں۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات آیت کے بنیادی پیغام کو برقرار رکھتی ہیں کہ مخلصانہ اخراجات - دور سے قطع نظر - الہی الہٰی بدلہ دیتے ہیں ، کیونکہ ریزی (مافاتیہ) اور تبتابائی مشترکہ طور پر ان کے اعمال کے بارے میں اللہ کے عداوت کے تجزیوں کے ذریعے تصدیق کرتے ہیں۔
10.summary: Drawing from Al-Mizan, Allama Tabatabai explains that tafsir al-Mizan, In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates this verse by emphasizing the ontological principle that all creation ultimately returns to Allah, the true Owner of the heavens and earth. This verse from Surah al-Hadid addresses the spiritual and social duty of spending (infaq) in Allah’s cause, emphasizing that true sacrifice gains greater merit when offered during times of hardship. The rhetorical question "Why do you not spend?" challenges believers to reflect on their attachment to worldly wealth, reminding them that everything in the heavens and earth ultimately belongs to Allah (وَلِلَّهِ مِيرَٰثُ ٱلسَّمَٰوَٰتِ وَٱلْأَرْضِ). The "conquest" (الفتح) refers to the pivotal 630 CE liberation of Makkah, when Islam transitioned from persecution to political ascendancy. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) explained: *"The ‘conquest’ refers to the establishment of the Prophet’s authority, and those who spent and struggled before it are the ones who recognized the truth of Wilayah in their hearts before it became manifest. By internalizing that wealth is a divine trust, believers cultivate detachment from materialism and invest in eternal rewards, trusting Allah’s awareness (خَبِيرٌ) of their intentions.
10.layer2short: In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates this verse by emphasizing the ontological principle that all creation ultimately returns to Allah, the true Owner of the heavens and earth. The rhetorical question "Why do you not spend in Allah’s cause?" underscores the paradox of human reluctance to expend transient wealth for eternal gain, given that all possessions are divine trusts. This establishes a theological framework wherein spending (infaq) becomes an act of restoring what rightfully belongs to Allah, aligning with the Shia understanding of *tawhid al-māl* (divine economic sovereignty).

11.layer1:
The verse from Surah Al-Hadid invites believers to reflect on the profound relationship between material sacrifice and spiritual reward. When Allah asks, *"Who is it that would loan Allah a goodly loan…"*, the metaphor of a "loan" (*qard*) underscores trust in divine reciprocity. In Shia tafsir, scholars like Allamah Tabatabai explain that *qardan hasanan* (a goodly loan) transcends monetary charity—it encompasses all acts of selfless giving for Allah’s pleasure, whether wealth, time, or effort. Historically, this verse resonated during early Islam’s struggles, urging support for the nascent Muslim community. Some narrations link it to contributions for jihad or aiding the vulnerable, reflecting the ethos of social responsibility central to the Prophet’s teachings and the Ahlul Bayt’s legacy.

Key terms hold layered meanings: *yuqridhu Allah* (lending to Allah) symbolizes the believer’s faith in unseen returns, while *yuda‘ifahu* (multiply it) assures exponential spiritual growth. The *ajrun karim* (noble reward) denotes both earthly blessings and eternal grace, echoing Imam Ali’s emphasis on sincerity in charity: "The best deed is that which is done with humility."

Today, this verse urges Muslims to invest in divine causes—supporting education, feeding the hungry, or upholding justice. It challenges materialism, reminding us that true wealth lies in giving without expectation. For Shia communities, this aligns with supporting Islamic institutions, caring for orphans, or contributing to projects that preserve the teachings of the Imams. Ultimately, the "loan" to Allah is a call to transcend transactional piety, embracing generosity as an expression of unwavering trust in His boundless mercy.
11.layer2:
In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates this verse as an invitation to transcend material attachment by investing in divine proximity. The "goodly loan" (*qardan hasanan*) is interpreted as acts of charity (*infaq*) performed purely for Allah’s pleasure, reflecting the Shia emphasis on *ikhlas* (sincerity) as the foundation of worship. Tabatabai underscores that such a "loan" is metaphorical, as Allah owns all existence; the believer’s sacrifice symbolises recognition of divine lordship and trust in transcendent recompense. The "multiplication" of the loan signifies both material and spiritual returns, with the latter—expressed as a "noble reward" (*ajrun karim*)—encompassing nearness to Allah and the intercession of the Ahlul Bayt (as) in the hereafter.

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, contextualises the verse within the Qur’anic paradigm of *tadarus al-nafs* (self-refinement), noting that charity purifies wealth and soul. Classical Shia commentaries, including those from the Imams, link this verse to supporting the cause of the Imamate. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) is reported to have stated that contributing to the welfare of believers—particularly through *khums* and *zakat*—constitutes this "loan," as it sustains the community of faith under divinely appointed leadership. This aligns with the Shia theological principle that material obligations are inseparable from spiritual allegiance (*walayah*) to the Ahlul Bayt.

The verse also integrates with Shia eschatology: the "noble reward" is interpreted as entry into Paradise through the intercession (*shafa’ah*) of the Imams, who embody divine mercy. Thus, the act of "lending" transcends transactional charity, becoming a means of participating in the cosmic justice established by Allah through His chosen guides. Such interpretations reinforce the Shia synthesis of jurisprudence and spirituality, where external acts of worship are pathways to internal transformation and eternal felicity.
11.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hadid’s 11th verse, Allah invites believers to “loan” Him through acts of virtue—a metaphor Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi contextualize as an investment in societal and spiritual capital. Contemporary interpretations emphasize that this “goodly loan” transcends mere financial charity, encompassing ethical labor, intellectual contributions, and environmental stewardship. Scholar Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari notes that the verse’s call for “multiplication” mirrors modern economic principles of sustainable growth, where small, intentional acts—like funding education or supporting green initiatives—yield exponential communal benefits over time.

Modern Shia discourse links this verse to pressing global challenges. For instance, addressing climate change becomes a form of “loaning” to future generations, aligning with Imam Ali’s teaching to “plant trees under whose shade you do not expect to sit.” Philosophically, the verse challenges hyper-individualism, urging a shift toward collective responsibility. Projects like microfinance programs in Shia-majority regions, such as Lebanon’s interest-free *qard al-hasan* loans, exemplify this ethos, empowering marginalized communities while fostering trust in divine reciprocity.

Interfaith parallels emerge in Judaism’s *tzedakah* (righteous giving) and Christian teachings on sacrificial charity, highlighting shared ethical foundations. In multicultural societies, this verse invites intercommunity solidarity—whether through disaster relief efforts or interfaith dialogues on economic justice. Ultimately, the “noble reward” isn’t merely otherworldly; it manifests as societal resilience, echoing Imam Sadiq’s wisdom: “The best deeds are those that endure.” By framing generosity as a transformative “loan,” the verse bridges divine trust with human agency, urging believers to co-create a world where compassion compounds like interest—unseen yet unstoppable.
11.layer4:
The verse of "the goodly loan" in Surah Al-Hadid is a divine invitation to transcend material attachments and invest in eternal realities. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) taught that this "loan" refers not merely to financial charity but to the total surrender of one’s self, wealth, and actions to Allah through the channel of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states: **"The best loan is to aid your brother in faith with your wealth, your tongue, and your hand"** (Bihar al-Anwar). This transforms charity into an act of spiritual commerce, where every sacrifice becomes a means of nearness to the Divine.

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her), in her timeless sermon, illuminated this truth: **"Allah made charity the purification of the soul and a growth in sustenance"** (Bihar al-Anwar). Here, the "noble reward" is not worldly recompense but the refinement of the soul and alignment with the Imamah’s luminous guidance. The verse’s call to "multiply" the loan echoes the Shia understanding that deeds gain value through sincere intention (*niyyah*) and adherence to the Imams’ teachings. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught: **"A dirham given in obedience is greater than a thousand spent in disobedience."**

Practically, this verse urges believers to view every act of generosity—whether wealth, time, or knowledge—as a sacred trust offered to Allah through love for His chosen ones. The "goodly loan" flourishes when given for His pleasure alone, free from ego or desire for praise. In the era of Imam Mahdi’s (may Allah hasten his reappearance) occultation, this verse becomes a roadmap: supporting the oppressed, upholding justice, and nurturing the community are forms of "lending" to Allah, awaiting the ultimate reward in His presence. As Imam al-Baqir (peace be upon him) said: **"The loan to Allah is the loan to His friends."** Thus, true giving is an affirmation of faith in the unseen, a bridge between the temporal and the eternal.
