17.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Hadid 57:17, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on the verse’s primary themes: Allah’s power to revive barren lands as a sign of His creative might and a metaphor for spiritual resurrection. Classical Sunni commentators like Tabari and Ibn Kathir emphasize the literal agricultural imagery, with Ibn Kathir linking it to physical resurrection (Tafsir Ibn Kathir), while Qurtubi extends this to moral revival through divine mercy (Al-Jami li-Ahkam al-Quran). Similarly, Shia scholars such as Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) and Tabrisi (Majma al-Bayan) acknowledge the literal meaning but prioritize its allegorical dimension, interpreting the “earth’s revival” as the awakening of human hearts through divine guidance, particularly through the Ahlul Bayt.

A key divergence lies in the theological implications of “revival.” Sunni scholars like Razi (Mafatih al-Ghayb) frame spiritual revival as contingent on communal adherence to Quranic teachings and Prophetic Sunnah. In contrast, Shia exegetes like Qummi (Tafsir al-Qummi) and Tusi (At-Tibyan) emphasize the necessity of Imamah, viewing the Imams as the means through which Allah perpetuates spiritual life after the Prophet’s death. This reflects the Shia theological axiom of continuous divine guidance through designated Imams, whereas Sunni interpretations align with the principle of collective guidance via the Quran and established tradition.

Historically, these differences stem from distinct epistemological frameworks: Shia tafsir integrates narrations from the Imams as divinely inspired hermeneutical tools, while Sunni exegesis prioritizes Prophetic hadith and consensus. Both traditions, however, share a practical emphasis on reflection (ta’aqqul) as the verse’s objective, urging believers to recognize divine power in natural and spiritual phenomena. This convergence underscores shared Islamic values, while divergent emphases on sources of authority illustrate the rich theological diversity within Quranic hermeneutics.

18.layer1:
Surah Al-Hadid verse 18 highlights the spiritual and social significance of sincere charity (sadaqah) in Islam, emphasizing that both men and women who engage in this virtue receive multiplied rewards from Allah. The verse uses the powerful metaphor of "loaning Allah a goodly loan" (aqradhu Allaha qardan hasanan), which classical Shia commentators like Allamah Tabatabai explain as acts of giving that transcend mere financial transactions. The "loan" represents trusting Allah completely, knowing He will repay believers with spiritual growth and eternal blessings far beyond worldly compensation.

Historically, this verse encouraged early Muslims during times of economic hardship to support the community selflessly. Scholars note it was revealed in Medina when the nascent Muslim society faced financial strain, urging believers to prioritize collective welfare over individual gain. The phrase "yuḍāʿaf lahum" (multiplied for them) underscores Allah’s boundless generosity – every act of charity, whether feeding the hungry, supporting orphans, or funding just causes, becomes an investment in divine mercy.

Key terms like "al-muṣaddiqīn" (those who verify truth through charity) derive from the root "ṣ-d-q," linking charity to truthfulness in faith. The "noble reward" (ajr karim) refers to both Paradise and the dignity earned by aligning one’s actions with divine purpose. For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites reflection on modern forms of sadaqah: donating to ethical causes, volunteering time, or using one’s skills for community benefit. It reminds us that true charity isn’t about the amount given but the sincerity (ikhlas) behind it – a principle upheld by the Ahlul Bayt, who taught that even a smile or kind word can be sadaqah. By viewing resources as trusts from Allah to be shared, believers cultivate detachment from materialism and strengthen social bonds, embodying the Quranic ideal of stewardship.
18.layer2:
In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates that the "goodly loan" (qardan hasanan) in this verse encompasses all acts of charity (sadaqah) and financial devotion to Allah’s cause, whether obligatory (wajib) or recommended (mustahabb). The metaphor of "loaning Allah" signifies that believers’ material sacrifices are not lost but reciprocated by divine generosity, transcending worldly transactional logic. Tabatabai emphasizes that the multiplication of reward ("yuda‘afu lahum") reflects Allah’s boundless grace, wherein even minor acts, when performed with sincerity (ikhlas), yield exponential spiritual dividends. This aligns with the Shia theological principle that divine recompense surpasses human deeds in both quantity and quality, rooted in Quranic notions of God’s justice (‘adl) and beneficence (lutf).

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, highlights that the verse addresses both men and women equally, underscoring the Shia emphasis on spiritual equity between genders. He interprets "noble reward" (ajrun karim) as eternal proximity to Allah and the intercession (shafa‘ah) of the Ahl al-Bayt, a concept central to Shia eschatology. The "loan" metaphor further implies trust (amanah) in Allah’s promise, requiring believers to prioritise metaphysical certainty (yaqin) over material attachment—a theme recurrent in sermons of Imam Ali, who likened worldly wealth to a transient loan (Ghaybat al-Nu‘mani).

Classical Shia jurisprudence links this verse to the obligation of khums and zakat, as financial worship purifies wealth and sustains communal welfare. Theologians like Shaykh al-Mufid connect such acts to the cultivation of taqwa and preparation for the Imam’s reappearance, framing charity as both individual duty and collective responsibility. Thus, the verse transcends mere economic ethics, encapsulating a holistic vision where material sacrifice becomes a conduit for spiritual transformation and alignment with divine will.
18.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hadid (57:18), the Quran elevates charitable acts as both spiritual investments and social imperatives. Contemporary Shia scholars, like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, emphasise that "loaning Allah a goodly loan" transcends transactional charity—it’s a call to systemic justice. This aligns with modern economic theories advocating wealth redistribution to address inequality, a theme echoed in Imam Ali’s Nahj al-Balagha: "The best charity is to satisfy a starving person."  

Psychologists like Elizabeth Dunn confirm that generosity activates brain regions linked to happiness, mirroring the verse’s promise of "multiplied" rewards. Here, divine wisdom intersects with neuroscience: altruism benefits both giver and receiver. Socially, the verse challenges neoliberal individualism by framing charity as communal responsibility—a concept vital for tackling crises like climate displacement or pandemic inequities.  

Modern scholars, including Dr. Reza Shah-Kazemi, contextualise this "loan" as sustainable giving: supporting education, healthcare, or green energy projects. Such interpretations resonate with interfaith efforts; Catholic relief agencies and Islamic zakat funds increasingly collaborate on refugee aid, embodying the verse’s universal ethics.  

In multicultural societies, the verse’s gender-inclusive language ("men and women who practice charity") gains relevance. Scholars like Dr. Leila Takim highlight its egalitarian vision, urging Muslim communities to empower women as equal stakeholders in philanthropy.  

Ultimately, this verse bridges divine trust and human agency: every act of generosity—whether a food bank donation or microloan—becomes a "noble reward" shaping a more equitable world. As climate disasters and economic divides intensify, its message transforms charity from piety to planetary survival.

In the luminous verse of Surah Al-Hadid, Allah elevates the spiritual station of those who give charity sincerely, framing it as a "goodly loan" returned with multiplied divine blessings. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) unveil profound layers of this metaphor, teaching that true charity transcends material wealth—it is an act of recognizing Allah’s sovereignty and affirming the Wilayah (divine guardianship) of His chosen guides. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states, *"The loan to Allah is the Imam’s right from the believers; fulfilling it purifies wealth and multiplies faith."* Here, charity becomes a covenant linking the believer’s heart to the Imamah, transforming mundane acts into spiritual investments.

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her), in her timeless sermon, illuminated that charity must flow from *"a heart softened by the remembrance of Allah, not by the desire for praise."* This aligns with Imam Sadiq’s (peace be upon him) teaching: *"When you give, let your hand be the lowest—like one indebted to Allah, not a benefactor."* True charity is humility in action, acknowledging that all provisions belong to Allah and that giving is merely returning a trust. The "noble reward" promised is not merely Paradise but nearness to the Divine—a station achieved through aligning one’s intentions with the Imams’ teachings.

Practically, the Ahlul Bayt urge believers to give *before* being asked, to prefer secrecy over show, and to prioritize the needy who uphold dignity. Imam Baqir (peace be upon him) taught that *"the best charity is given while your soul still clings to it"—*a test of detachment from worldly attachments. By internalizing these truths, every act of generosity becomes a step toward spiritual refinement, a testament to living Wilayah, and a bridge to the eternal "noble reward" reserved for the lovers of the Ahlul Bayt.

18.layer5:
In interpreting Quran 57:18, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core principles while offering distinct emphases rooted in their theological frameworks. Classical commentators across traditions, including Tabari and Tabatabai, agree that "loaning Allah a goodly loan" metaphorically denotes sincere charity (sadaqa) and financial devotion to divine causes. Ibn Kathir and Tabrisi both highlight the Prophet's teachings that such acts yield multiplied spiritual rewards, with Qurtubi adding that this includes both obligatory zakat and voluntary giving.  

A key divergence emerges in defining the recipients and purposes of charity. Sunni works like Razi's *Mafatih al-Ghayb* emphasize broad social welfare, interpreting "goodly loan" as supporting communal needs through institutions like mosques and public trusts. In contrast, Shia sources such as Qummi's tafsir and Tusi's *At-Tibyan* connect the verse to supporting the Ahlul Bayt's leadership, viewing charity as both spiritual investment and means of maintaining the Imams' mission during occultation. Tabatabai's *Al-Mizan* further spiritualizes the concept, framing the "loan" as cultivating nearness to Allah through the Imams' walaya.  

These interpretations reflect historical contexts: Sunni emphasis on communal stability emerged amid early caliphal efforts to consolidate social institutions, while Shia readings developed during periods of political marginalization where supporting Imami leadership became an act of faith. Practically, this manifests in differing charitable priorities - Sunni jurists like Qurtubi stress generalized poverty alleviation, whereas Shia fiqh often designates specific funds (like khums) for religious leadership.  

Both traditions maintain that sincere intention (niyya) determines the deed's value, as noted by Tabari and Majma al-Bayan. However, the theological lens through which "divine loan" is understood - whether as generalized social covenant or as commitment to divinely appointed guidance - remains shaped by distinct conceptions of religious authority preserved through centuries of interpretive tradition.

وصول کنندگان اور خیرات کے مقاصد کی وضاحت میں ایک اہم موڑ ابھرتا ہے۔ سنی ریزی کی * مافاتیہ الغیب * کی طرح کام کرتی ہے ، وسیع معاشرتی بہبود پر زور دیتی ہے ، اور "اچھے قرض" کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے مساجد اور عوامی امانتوں جیسے اداروں کے ذریعہ فرقہ وارانہ ضروریات کی حمایت کرتی ہے۔ اس کے برعکس ، شیعہ ذرائع جیسے قمی کے طافسیر اور توسی کے * ایٹ تبیان * آیت کو اہل بیت کی قیادت کی حمایت کرنے سے مربوط کرتے ہیں ، اور خیراتی ادارے کو روحانی سرمایہ کاری اور جادو کے دوران اماموں کے مشن کو برقرار رکھنے کے ذرائع دونوں کے طور پر دیکھتے ہیں۔ تبتابائی کا * المزان * اس تصور کو مزید روحانی شکل دیتا ہے ، اور "قرض" کو اماموں کے والیا کے ذریعہ اللہ کے ساتھ قربت کاشت کرنے کے طور پر تیار کرتا ہے۔  

یہ تشریحات تاریخی سیاق و سباق کی عکاسی کرتی ہیں: سماجی اداروں کو مستحکم کرنے کے لئے ابتدائی خلاصہ کوششوں کے درمیان فرقہ وارانہ استحکام پر سنی پر زور سامنے آیا ، جبکہ شیعہ ریڈنگ سیاسی پسماندگی کے ادوار کے دوران تیار ہوئی جہاں امامی قیادت کی حمایت کرنے والا ایک عمل بن گیا۔ عملی طور پر ، یہ مختلف رفاہی ترجیحات میں ظاہر ہوتا ہے - قربانی جیسے سنی فقیہ نے غربت کے خاتمے کو عام کیا ، جبکہ شیعہ فیقہ اکثر مذہبی قیادت کے لئے مخصوص فنڈز (جیسے خموں) کو نامزد کرتا ہے۔  

دونوں روایات برقرار رکھتے ہیں کہ مخلص ارادے (نیایا) عمل کی قدر کا تعین کرتے ہیں ، جیسا کہ تباری اور مجس البیان نے نوٹ کیا ہے۔ تاہم ، مذہبی عینک جس کے ذریعے "الہی قرض" سمجھا جاتا ہے - چاہے عام معاشرتی عہد کے طور پر ہو یا الہٰی مقرر کردہ رہنمائی کے عزم کے طور پر - صدیوں کی تشریحی روایت کے دوران محفوظ مذہبی اتھارٹی کے الگ الگ تصورات کی تشکیل کی گئی ہے۔

18.layer2short: In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates that the "goodly loan" (qardan hasanan) in this verse encompasses all acts of charity (sadaqah) and financial devotion to Allah’s cause, whether obligatory (wajib) or recommended (mustahabb). The metaphor of "loaning Allah" signifies that believers’ material sacrifices are not lost but reciprocated by divine generosity, transcending worldly transactional logic. Tabatabai emphasizes that the multiplication of reward ("yuda‘afu lahum") reflects Allah’s boundless grace, wherein even minor acts, when performed with sincerity (ikhlas), yield exponential spiritual dividends. This aligns with the Shia theological principle that divine recompense surpasses human deeds in both quantity and quality, rooted in Quranic notions of God’s justice (‘adl) and beneficence (lutf).
18.layer2short_urdu: *طافسیر المزان *میں ، علامہ تبتابائی نے اس آیت میں "اچھ loan ے قرض" (قرطان حسنن) کی وضاحت کی ہے کہ اس آیت میں تمام صدقہ (صدقہ) اور اللہ کے مقصد کے لئے مالی عقیدت کا احاطہ کیا گیا ہے ، چاہے وہ واجب الادا (واجیب) ہو یا سفارش کی گئی ہو (مستحاب)۔ "لوننگ اللہ" کا استعارہ اس بات کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے کہ مومنوں کی مادی قربانییں ضائع نہیں ہوتی ہیں بلکہ خدائی سخاوت کے ذریعہ اس کا بدلہ لیا جاتا ہے ، اور دنیاوی لین دین کی منطق سے بالاتر ہے۔ تبتابائی نے اس بات پر زور دیا ہے کہ اجر کی ضرب ("یودا آفو لاہوم") اللہ کے بے حد فضل کی عکاسی کرتی ہے ، جس میں یہاں تک کہ معمولی حرکتوں میں بھی ، جب اخلاص (اکھلاس) کے ساتھ انجام دیا جاتا ہے تو ، اس میں روحانی منافع حاصل ہوتا ہے۔ یہ شیعہ مذہبی اصول کے ساتھ منسلک ہے کہ الہی بدلہ خدا کے انصاف (‘ADL) اور فائدہ (LUTF) کے قرآنی نظریات میں جڑیں ، مقدار اور معیار دونوں میں انسانی اعمال کو پیچھے چھوڑ دیتا ہے۔

19.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hadid, verse 19, Allah distinguishes between two groups: the sincere believers and those who reject truth. The verse opens by praising *alladhina amanu billahi wa rusulihi*—those who believe in Allah and His messengers. These individuals are elevated to the ranks of *as-siddiqun* (the truthful ones) and *ash-shuhada* (the witnesses or martyrs). In Shia tafsir, *siddiqun* refers to those whose faith transcends mere verbal affirmation, embodying unwavering truthfulness in thought and action. Historically, this term is closely tied to figures like Lady Fatima al-Zahra and the Imams of Ahlul Bayt, who exemplified perfect alignment between belief and conduct. The term *shuhada* here carries dual meaning: martyrs who sacrifice for truth, and spiritual "witnesses" who testify to divine reality through their lives. Classical commentators like Tabatabai note that *shuhada* in this context also alludes to the Ahlul Bayt’s role as living witnesses of Allah’s message across generations.  

The verse’s Medinan context reflects a community navigating challenges of hypocrisy and external threats. It reassures believers that their spiritual efforts—rooted in faith and justice—earn divine reward (*ajr*) and enlightenment (*nur*), while rejecters face eternal loss. Key terms like *nur* (light) symbolise the guidance and clarity faith provides, contrasting with the darkness of disbelief.  

For modern Muslims, this verse emphasises sincerity as the core of faith. It calls for aligning actions with belief, resisting societal pressures to compromise principles, and drawing inspiration from the Ahlul Bayt’s example of steadfastness. The concept of being *shuhada* challenges believers to actively "bear witness" to truth through moral courage, social justice, and defending the vulnerable—a timeless duty in an era of moral ambiguity. By embodying *sidq* (truthfulness) in daily life, Muslims uphold the legacy of the *siddiqun*, ensuring their spiritual legacy transcends mere ritual into transformative, illuminated living.
19.layer2:
In Surah al-Hadid (57:19), the Qur’an delineates the spiritual hierarchy of believers, a theme deeply expounded in Shia exegesis. Classical commentators such as Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Shaykh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasize that the designation of believers as *al-siddiqun* (the truthful) and *al-shuhada* (the witnesses) transcends literal meanings, reflecting ontological realities tied to divine covenant and wilaya (guardianship). Tabatabai interprets *siddiqun* as those whose inner certainty (yaqin) aligns perfectly with outward action, embodying the station of "truthfulness in all states" — a rank epitomized by the Ahl al-Bayt, whom Shia tradition regards as the perfected heirs of prophetic truth.  

The term *shuhada* is understood not merely as martyrs but as "witnesses" who testify to divine reality through their existential submission. Tabrisi notes this role extends to eschatological witnessing, where the righteous — particularly the Imams — bear witness to the deeds of humanity before Allah, resonating with the Shia concept of intercession (shafa‘a). The "reward" and "light" promised to them signify both paradisal recompense and the illumination of divine guidance (nur al-hidaya), which Shia theology associates with the Imams’ role as luminous guides (as affirmed in Hadith al-Thaqalayn).  

Contrastingly, the verse’s condemnation of deniers underscores the Shia doctrine of divine justice (‘adl), wherein rejection of Allah’s signs — including the Imamate as a manifest sign (ayat) — merits eternal separation from mercy. This dichotomy between the *siddiqun* and the *ashab al-jahim* reflects the cosmic balance between wilaya and kufr (disbelief), central to Shia soteriology. The verse thus encapsulates the interplay of faith, divine authority, and eschatological accountability, grounding believers in the necessity of allegiance to both Allah’s message and its designated custodians.
19.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Hadid 57:19 is often interpreted as a dynamic call to embody truth (siddiqun) and bear witness (shuhada) to justice in an age of moral complexity. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his exegesis, emphasizes that "siddiqun" today includes not only unwavering faith but also intellectual integrity—aligning religious conviction with rational inquiry, a theme echoed by scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, who links the verse to the pursuit of truth in science and ethics. The "light" promised to believers is framed as both spiritual guidance and the clarity gained through critical engagement with knowledge, resonating with modern discussions on enlightenment through education and technology.  

Socially, the verse’s contrast between truth-affirmers and deniers speaks to contemporary struggles against misinformation, systemic oppression, and climate denial. Scholars like Sayyid Ammar Nakshawani contextualize "denying Our signs" as rejecting both Quranic ethics and empirical evidence, such as environmental stewardship—a stance aligning with Shia environmental theology that views ecological collapse as a moral failure. Philosophically, the "shuhada" (witnesses) are reinterpreted as those who testify to truth through activism, such as advocates for social justice or victims of tyranny, reflecting Imam Hussein’s legacy of principled resistance.  

Interfaith perspectives highlight shared values: the "supporters of truth" transcend religious boundaries, uniting diverse communities in combating poverty or extremism. This verse challenges modern societies to cultivate moral courage—whether through interfaith dialogue, scientific collaboration, or ethical governance—while warning against the "hellfire" of divisive ideologies or apathy. Ultimately, it bridges divine promise with human responsibility, urging believers to illuminate a fractured world through faith-rooted action.
19.layer4:
In the luminous verse of Surah al-Hadid (57:19), Allah distinguishes between those anchored in divine truth and those consumed by denial. The Ahlul Bayt (as) unveil profound layers here: Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) states, *"The Siddiqun [truthful ones] are the Imams from the Progeny of Muhammad (pbuh), for they are the embodiment of truthfulness in word, action, and essence"* (Tafsir al-Burhan). This elevates the verse beyond general faith—it binds belief in Allah and His messengers to unwavering recognition of the Imams’ divine guardianship (Wilayah). The "light" promised to believers is interpreted as the Nur of Ahlul Bayt, which Imam Ali (as) called *"the lanterns of wisdom in the darkness of ignorance"* (Nahj al-Balagha).  

Lady Fatimah (as) illuminates the practical dimension: *"The light of the believer is their submission to Allah’s command, manifested through love for His chosen ones"* (Bihar al-Anwar). To attain this light, one must align their heart with the Imams’ teachings—turning every prayer, struggle, and act of charity into a mirror reflecting their spiritual station. The "Shuhada" (martyrs) here include not only those who physically sacrifice but also those who "die" to ego by upholding justice amid oppression, as Imam Hussain (as) exemplified at Karbala.  

The verse’s warning against denial extends to rejecting the Imams’ divine authority—a rejection that severs the soul from its luminous source. To embody this truth, believers must immerse themselves in the Qur’an and the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings, for Imam Muhammad al-Baqir (as) taught, *"Our Wilayah is the covenant of Allah; whoever holds fast to it enters Paradise"* (Al-Kafi). Thus, spiritual development hinges on nurturing loyalty to the Imams, transforming faith into a living, radiant certainty that guides every step toward the Divine.

سورہ الحدید ، آیت 19 میں ، اللہ دو گروہوں کے درمیان تمیز کرتا ہے: مخلص مومنین اور جو سچائی کو مسترد کرتے ہیں۔ یہ آیت *الادھینا امانو بلاہی وا رسولیہی *کی تعریف کرتے ہوئے کھلتی ہے۔ ان افراد کو * ASDIDIQUN * (سچے والے) اور * ایش شوہاڈا * (گواہوں یا شہدا) کی صفوں میں بلند کیا جاتا ہے۔ شیعہ طافسیر میں ، * صدیقون * سے مراد ان لوگوں سے ہے جن کا عقیدہ محض زبانی تصدیق سے بالاتر ہے ، جو فکر اور عمل میں غیر متزلزل سچائی کو مجسم بناتا ہے۔ تاریخی طور پر ، اس اصطلاح کو لیڈی فاطمہ الزہرا اور اہل بیت کے امام جیسی شخصیات سے قریب سے جڑا ہوا ہے ، جنہوں نے اعتقاد اور طرز عمل کے مابین کامل صف بندی کی مثال دی۔ اصطلاح * شاہڈا * یہاں دوہری معنی رکھتی ہے: شہداء جو سچائی کے لئے قربانی دیتے ہیں ، اور روحانی "گواہ" جو اپنی زندگی کے ذریعے الہی حقیقت کی گواہی دیتے ہیں۔ تبتابائی جیسے کلاسیکی مبصرین نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ * شوہاڈا * اس تناظر میں بھی نسلوں میں اللہ کے پیغام کے زندہ گواہوں کی حیثیت سے اہل بیت کے کردار کی نشاندہی کرتے ہیں۔  

آیت کا مدین سیاق و سباق ایک کمیونٹی کی عکاسی کرتا ہے جو منافقت اور بیرونی خطرات کے چیلنجوں کو دیکھ رہا ہے۔ اس سے مومنین کو یقین دلایا جاتا ہے کہ ان کی روحانی کاوشوں - عقیدے اور انصاف میں جڑی ہوئی ہے۔ * نور * (روشنی) جیسی کلیدی اصطلاحات رہنمائی اور واضحیت کے اعتراف کی علامت ہیں ، جو کفر کے اندھیرے سے متصادم ہیں۔  

جدید مسلمانوں کے ل this ، یہ آیت اخلاص پر زور دیتی ہے کہ وہ عقیدہ کی حیثیت رکھتا ہے۔ اس میں اصولوں سے سمجھوتہ کرنے کے لئے معاشرتی دباؤ کی مزاحمت ، اور اہل بیت کی ثابت قدمی کی مثال سے متاثر ہونے کے لئے معاشرتی دباؤ کی مزاحمت کرنے ، اور اصولوں سے متاثر ہونے کا مطالبہ کیا گیا ہے۔ * شوہا * ہونے کا تصور مومنوں کو چیلنج کرتا ہے کہ وہ اخلاقی ہمت ، معاشرتی انصاف ، اور کمزوروں کا دفاع کرنا اخلاقی ابہام کے دور میں ایک لازوال ڈیوٹی کے ذریعہ سچائی کے لئے "گواہ" کو فعال طور پر "گواہ" بنائے۔ روز مرہ کی زندگی میں *سدق *(سچائی) کو مجسم بناتے ہوئے ، مسلمان *صدیقون *کی میراث کو برقرار رکھتے ہیں ، اور ان کی روحانی میراث کو یقینی بناتے ہوئے محض رسم کو تبدیلی ، روشن زندگی میں ماورا ہے۔
19.layer2_urdu:

اس کے برعکس ، اس آیت کی تردید کرنے والوں کی مذمت شیعہ نظریہ الہی انصاف (‘ADL) کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے ، جس میں اللہ کی علامتوں کو مسترد کرنا ہے - جس میں امامیٹ بھی شامل ہے جس میں ایک مظہر علامت (آیت) بھی شامل ہے - رحمت سے ابدی علیحدگی کی خوبی ہے۔ * سددقون * اور * اشاب الجاہیم * کے مابین یہ دوچوٹومی شیعہ سوٹریولوجی کے وسط میں ، ولیا اور کوفر (کفر) کے مابین کائناتی توازن کی عکاسی کرتی ہے۔ اس طرح یہ آیت ایمان ، الہی اتھارٹی ، اور ایسکیٹولوجیکل احتساب کے باہمی تعل .ق کا احاطہ کرتی ہے ، اور مومنوں کو اللہ کے پیغام اور اس کے نامزد کردہ متعدد نگہبانوں کی وفاداری کی ضرورت کے مطابق بناتی ہے۔

19.layer5:
Both Shia and Sunni exegetes concur that this verse elevates believers who uphold divine truth (*siddiqun*) and bear witness to faith (*shuhada*) as recipients of divine reward and spiritual illumination. Tabari (Sunni) and Tabatabai (Shia) agree that *siddiqun* denotes those whose actions align perfectly with their professed faith, embodying unwavering truthfulness. Ibn Kathir and Al-Tibyan (Tusi) similarly stress that martyrs (*shuhada*) include both those who physically die for faith and those who "bear witness" to truth through righteous living, reflecting a shared emphasis on spiritual and physical sacrifice.  

Divergences emerge in defining the scope of *siddiqun*. Sunni commentators like Qurtubi and Razi interpret the term broadly, encompassing all truthful believers, including the Prophet’s companions. Ibn Kathir explicitly links *siddiqun* to early Muslims like Abu Bakr, reinforcing Sunni reverence for the *sahaba*. In contrast, Shia sources such as Al-Mizan (Tabatabai) and Majma al-Bayan (Tabrisi) emphasize the term’s singular excellence, reserving it for the Prophet’s household (*Ahl al-Bayt*) and Imams, whom they regard as infallible bearers of divine truth. Al-Qummi’s tafsir further ties this rank to the Imams’ role as spiritual guides, reflecting Shia theological doctrines on *wilayah* (divine guardianship).  

These interpretations influence religious practice: Sunni traditions encourage emulation of the *sahaba*, while Shia communities emphasize devotion to the Imams. The divergence stems from historical debates over leadership after the Prophet, with Shia exegesis developing within a framework prioritizing the *Ahl al-Bayt*’s authority. Despite these differences, both traditions unite in viewing the verse as a call to embody truthfulness and prepare for divine accountability—a convergence underscoring shared ethical priorities in Islamic spirituality.

In Surah Al-Hadid, verse 19, Allah distinguishes between two groups: the sincere believers and those who reject truth. The verse opens by praising *alladhina amanu billahi wa rusulihi*—those who believe in Allah and His messengers. These individuals are elevated to the ranks of *as-siddiqun* (the truthful ones) and *ash-shuhada* (the witnesses or martyrs). Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) states, *"The Siddiqun [truthful ones] are the Imams from the Progeny of Muhammad (pbuh), for they are the embodiment of truthfulness in word, action, and essence"* (Tafsir al-Burhan). By embodying *sidq* (truthfulness) in daily life, Muslims uphold the legacy of the *siddiqun*, ensuring their spiritual legacy transcends mere ritual into transformative, illuminated living.

20.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hadid, verse 20, Allah paints a vivid contrast between the fleeting distractions of worldly life (*dunya*) and the eternal reality of the hereafter (*akhirah*). The verse opens with a striking declaration: *"Know that the life of this world is but amusement and diversion..."* Here, key Arabic terms like *la’ib* (play), *lahw* (frivolous diversion), and *zeenah* (superficial adornment) expose the emptiness of pursuits rooted in vanity, materialism, and social competition (*takathur*). The imagery of rain nourishing crops that briefly delight farmers before withering into debris underscores life’s impermanence—a metaphor scholars like Allamah Tabatabai explain as a warning against mistaking temporary pleasures for true success.  

Historical context suggests this verse resonated with early Muslims navigating newfound prosperity after early conquests, reminding them that wealth and status are tests, not ends. The Ahlul Bayt, particularly Imam Ali, emphasized this theme, cautioning in Nahjul Balagha that *dunya* is a "place of passage, not permanence." The verse’s closing line—*"the worldly life is but the enjoyment of delusion"*—calls believers to awaken from the *ghurur* (deception) of prioritizing transient gains over lasting spiritual investment.  

For modern Muslims, this verse invites self-reflection: Are we chasing wealth, status, or appearances to the neglect of faith, justice, and compassion? It teaches balance—engaging responsibly in worldly affairs while anchoring our hearts in the *akhirah*. Practical steps include avoiding extravagance, cultivating gratitude, and investing in deeds that outlive us, like charity (*sadaqah*) and nurturing community ties. By recognizing *dunya* as a fleeting test, we can redirect our energy toward earning Allah’s *maghfirah* (forgiveness) and *ridwan* (pleasure), the true measures of success.
20.layer2:
In his seminal exegesis *Al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates Surah al-Hadid 20 by framing the worldly life (*dunya*) as a transient illusion distracting humanity from eternal truths. The verse’s five descriptors—"play, diversion, adornment, boasting, and competition"—are interpreted as manifestations of humanity’s preoccupation with ephemeral pursuits, which Shia theology identifies as spiritual veils (*ghurur*) obscuring the recognition of divine purpose. Tabatabai emphasizes that worldly attachments, including wealth and progeny, are not inherently condemned but become spiritually perilous when prioritized over the cultivation of faith and preparation for the Hereafter. The agricultural metaphor—wherein flourishing plants wither into debris—symbolizes the futility of investing solely in material outcomes devoid of transcendent meaning.

Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* expands on this imagery, noting that the "rain" represents divine blessings misappropriated by those who mistake temporary abundance for lasting success. The "kuffar" (tillers) here signify not only disbelievers but also those spiritually heedless, including nominal Muslims fixated on worldly validation. Shia commentators uniquely link this heedlessness to the abandonment of *walayah* (allegiance to divine guidance through the Ahl al-Bayt), as Imam Jafar al-Sadiq states: "The world is a bridge; cross it, do not dwell upon it." 

The verse’s conclusion juxtaposes divine mercy (*maghfirah*) and pleasure (*ridwan*) in the Hereafter with worldly delusion, underscoring the Shia theological axiom that true felicity lies in aligning one’s actions with the eternal scales of justice (*‘adl*) and the intercession (*shafa‘ah*) of the Imams. This duality informs Shia jurisprudence, which prioritizes detachment (*zuhd*) from materialism while encouraging ethical engagement with worldly responsibilities as acts of worship. Thus, the verse encapsulates the Shia ethos of navigating temporal existence as a means to eternal proximity to Allah, guided by the luminous teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt.
20.layer3:
Contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasr Makarim Shirazi and Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari interpret Surah Al-Hadid 20 as a profound critique of materialism and short-termism in modern society. They emphasize that the verse’s agricultural metaphor—comparing worldly pursuits to ephemeral plant growth—resonates with ecological insights on sustainability. The rapid growth and decay of crops mirror humanity’s extractive economies, where fleeting gains in wealth or status (amplified by social media’s “adornment and boasting”) eclipse long-term spiritual and environmental consequences. Scholar Dr. Liyakat Takim notes that this verse challenges the “growth-at-all-costs” mindset driving climate crises, urging believers to prioritize *akhirah*-oriented stewardship over destructive consumerism.  

Philosophically, thinkers like Dr. Shomali (ICAS) link the “enjoyment of delusion” to modern anxieties rooted in hyper-competition and hollow digital validation. The verse’s warning against *takathur* (competitive accumulation) speaks to widening inequality and mental health crises, where self-worth is tied to material metrics. Interfaith dialogues—such as those with Buddhist scholars on *anicca* (impermanence)—highlight shared wisdom on detachment from transient pursuits.  

Modern tafsir also addresses systemic injustices: the “dry debris” of exploited resources parallels marginalized communities bearing the brunt of environmental collapse. Ayatollah Fadlallah’s legacy frames this verse as a call to ethical resistance—redirecting energy from “play and diversion” toward justice and divine proximity. In an age of AI and deepfakes, the “delusion” of worldly life demands critical media literacy and spiritual vigilance, anchoring identity not in algorithms but in transcendent purpose. Ultimately, this verse invites a reevaluation of success, urging societies to cultivate *rida* (divine approval) through compassion and sustainable coexistence.
20.layer4:
In this profound verse, Allah unveils the ephemeral nature of worldly life through the lens of divine reality as taught by the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). Imam Ali (as) states in Nahj al-Balagha: "The world is a corpse, and its seekers are dogs." This shocking metaphor pierces through illusions, teaching that worldly pursuits – wealth, status, and material competition – are decaying distractions from eternal truth. The Imams (as) emphasize that this "enjoyment of delusion" refers to mistaking temporary pleasures for true success, blinding hearts from recognizing their Creator and the eternal abode.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) explains the verse's agricultural metaphor spiritually: "The 'crop' that pleases disbelievers represents worldly attachments that sprout in hearts, only to wither when death exposes their emptiness." The true harvest, he teaches, is cultivated through remembrance of Allah and obedience to the Imam of one's time – for wilayah (divine guardianship) is the water that nourishes eternal gardens. Lady Fatimah (as) warned in her famous sermon: "Beware the world's sweetness, for it poisons hearts with love of transient things."

Practical wisdom from the Infallibles directs believers to: 1) Measure all actions by their afterlife weight, as Imam Zain al-Abideen (as) teaches in Sahifa Sajjadiyyah 2) Cultivate detachment through daily reflection on mortality 3) Channel worldly means toward spiritual ends – using wealth for charity, status for promoting justice, and familial ties for nurturing God-consciousness. The path to escaping delusion lies in anchoring one's heart to the "strong rope" of Ahlul Bayt's guidance, transforming worldly life into a field sown with seeds for Paradise.

20.layer5:
In interpreting Surah al-Hadid 57:20, Shia and Sunni exegetes broadly concur on the verse’s central theme: the transient nature of worldly life and the imperative to prioritize spiritual preparation for the hereafter. Both traditions cite the agricultural metaphor—wherein flourishing vegetation swiftly decays—as illustrating the futility of material attachment. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) similarly emphasize that worldly pursuits like wealth accumulation and social rivalry distract from eternal truths, with al-Tabari noting the Quraysh’s pre-Islamic materialism as historical context, while al-Tabrisi links this to Quranic warnings against "ghurur" (delusion). Al-Qurtubi (Sunni) and al-Tusi (Shia) both stress that the verse does not condemn lawful enjoyment but warns against mistaking temporal comforts for ultimate success.

Key divergences emerge in theological nuance. Shia commentaries, particularly al-Mizan by Tabatabai, often contextualize worldly detachment within the framework of divine guardianship (wilayah), viewing neglect of the Ahl al-Bayt’s guidance as the pinnacle of delusion. Al-Qummi’s tafsir cites Imam al-Sadiq’s interpretation that "boasting" refers to sectarian divisions opposing the Imams. Sunni exegetes like Ibn Kathir and al-Razi focus more generically on individual accountability, with al-Razi philosophically analyzing worldly "play" (la‘ib) as purposeless activity divorced from worship. While Ibn Kathir cites hadiths urging moderation in worldly engagement, Shia sources tie this moderation to allegiance to the Imams’ teachings.

Historically, these differences reflect distinct epistemological priorities: Shia tafsir integrates the Imams’ hermeneutical authority, whereas Sunni works prioritize prophetic traditions (hadith) and companion narratives. Practically, Shia interpretations may amplify critiques of political power structures absent in Sunni readings, given the latter’s historical ties to caliphal systems. Both traditions, however, reinforce ethical imperatives toward charity and spiritual vigilance, demonstrating shared moral concerns beneath interpretive variations.

20.summary: Tafsir al-Mizan provides insight, noting that his seminal exegesis *Al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates Surah al-Hadid 20 by framing the worldly life (*dunya*) as a transient illusion distracting humanity from eternal truths. In Surah Al-Hadid, verse 20, Allah paints a vivid contrast between the fleeting distractions of worldly life (*dunya*) and the eternal reality of the hereafter (*akhirah*). The verse opens with a striking declaration: *"Know that the life of this world is but amusement and diversion. "* Here, key Arabic terms like *la’ib* (play), *lahw* (frivolous diversion), and *zeenah* (superficial adornment) expose the emptiness of pursuits rooted in vanity, materialism, and social competition (*takathur*). Imam Ali (as) states in Nahj al-Balagha: "The world is a corpse, and its seekers are dogs. This verse invites self-reflection: Are we chasing wealth, status, or appearances to the neglect of faith, justice, and compassion? It teaches balance—engaging responsibly in worldly affairs while anchoring our hearts in the *akhirah*.
20.layer2short: In his seminal exegesis *Al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates Surah al-Hadid 20 by framing the worldly life (*dunya*) as a transient illusion distracting humanity from eternal truths. The verse’s five descriptors—"play, diversion, adornment, boasting, and competition"—are interpreted as manifestations of humanity’s preoccupation with ephemeral pursuits, which Shia theology identifies as spiritual veils (*ghurur*) obscuring the recognition of divine purpose. Tabatabai emphasizes that worldly attachments, including wealth and progeny, are not inherently condemned but become spiritually perilous when prioritized over the cultivation of faith and preparation for the Hereafter. The agricultural metaphor—wherein flourishing plants wither into debris—symbolizes the futility of investing solely in material outcomes devoid of transcendent meaning.

21.layer1:
In Surah Al-Hadid 57:21, Allah invites believers to hasten toward *maghfira* (forgiveness) and a *jannah* (Paradise) as vast as the heavens and earth. The verse’s urgent tone—using the command *sabiqu* (race)—emphasizes proactive spiritual striving. Historical context suggests this Medinan verse addressed early Muslims transitioning from persecution to community-building, reminding them that material success must not overshadow eternal goals. Shia tafsir, as noted by scholars like Allamah Tabatabai, highlights that true *iman* (faith) in Allah and His messengers inherently includes loyalty to the divine guidance embodied by the Ahlul Bayt, as their leadership completes the message of prophethood.

The phrase *"arduha ka-ardi as-sama wal-ard"* (width like the heavens and earth) symbolizes Paradise’s boundless mercy, reflecting Allah’s infinite capacity to reward. Key terms like *fadl* (bounty) stress that divine grace isn’t earned by merit alone but granted through Allah’s wisdom—a concept harmonizing human effort with reliance on divine will. Shia tradition interprets this *fadl* as intertwined with adherence to the Imams, who are channels of Allah’s mercy.

Today, this verse calls Muslims to balance worldly responsibilities with spiritual priorities. "Racing" translates to competing in goodness: seeking knowledge, nurturing empathy, and upholding justice. In an age of distraction, it reminds us that Paradise isn’t passive reward but a destination requiring conscious effort—like supporting marginalized communities or resisting moral complacency. The verse also comforts believers: no struggle is too small, for Allah’s *fadl al-azim* (great bounty) surpasses human limitations. By anchoring actions in faith and divine love, Muslims transform daily life into a journey toward that eternal expanse.
21.layer2:
In interpreting Surah al-Hadid 21, classical Shia exegetes emphasise the ontological and spiritual dimensions of the divine call to "race" (sabiqoo) toward divine forgiveness and the celestial Garden. Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, elucidates that the imperative to "compete" denotes urgency in performing righteous deeds and cultivating inner virtues, framing it as a perpetual struggle (jihad al-nafs) against worldly distractions. The metaphor of the Garden’s width equalling "the heavens and earth" is interpreted as transcending physical spatiality; Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* posits this signifies the boundless, all-encompassing nature of divine mercy and the ontological vastness of the hereafter, which mirrors the cosmic scale of Allah’s creative power (qudrah).  

The verse’s specification that Paradise is "prepared for those who believed in Allah and His messengers" is contextualised within Shia theology as implicitly encompassing belief in the wilayah (guardianship) of the Ahl al-Bayt. As narrated in traditions from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, true faith (iman) necessitates recognition of the Imams’ divinely ordained authority, integrating theological conviction with practical obedience. This aligns with the Shia principle that belief in Allah’s messengers is incomplete without allegiance to their purified successors, a theme recurrent in hadith literature.  

The concluding phrase—"That is the bounty of Allah which He gives to whom He wills"—underscores the interplay between divine grace (lutf) and human agency. Classical commentators stress that while Allah’s favour is sovereign, it is attained through aligning one’s will with His via adherence to the Prophetic sunnah and the Imams’ teachings. Jurisprudentially, this verse reinforces the Shia understanding of tawalli (loving the Ahl al-Bayt) and tabarri (dissociating from their enemies) as integral to righteous action. Thus, the "race" toward forgiveness becomes a holistic pursuit of spiritual and ethical excellence anchored in the teachings of the Thaqalayn (Quran and Ahl al-Bayt), reflecting the Shia synthesis of doctrine, devotion, and divine grace.
21.layer3:
In Surah Al-Hadid’s 21st verse, the Quran’s call to “race toward forgiveness” and a cosmic-scale Paradise resonates powerfully in modern Shia thought. Contemporary scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasize this “race” as a dynamic, collective spiritual and ethical struggle (jihad al-nafs) against complacency. The verse’s imagery of a Garden “as wide as the heavens and earth” invites scientific reflection: astrophysicists describe the observable universe as approximately 93 billion light-years in diameter, a metaphor for divine generosity transcending human limits. Scholar Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali notes this mirrors Imam Ali’s teaching that “Allah’s mercy is vaster than His wrath,” urging believers to align personal growth with universal compassion.  

Socially, the verse’s urgency is applied to global crises. Grand Ayatollah Hussein Ismail al-Sadr interprets “racing” as mobilizing for climate justice, poverty alleviation, and interfaith solidarity—acts reflecting true faith in Allah’s messengers, who universally championed human dignity. Philosophically, the “width” of Paradise challenges narrow worldviews, encouraging Muslims to engage pluralistically. The Islamic College’s Dr. Rebecca Masterton links this to contemporary debates on religious exclusivism, arguing the verse’s inclusivity—Paradise being “prepared for those who believed”—harmonizes with Shia emphasis on divine grace over rigid sectarianism.  

In an era of polarization, this verse becomes a manifesto for proactive hope: spiritual ambition fused with social responsibility. As Iranian philosopher Abdolkarim Soroush observed, the “bounty of Allah” manifests not just in the hereafter but in humanity’s capacity to expand moral horizons—a celestial width made earthly through justice.
21.layer4:
In this profound verse, Allah invites believers to hasten towards divine forgiveness and a Paradise spanning the heavens and earth. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that this "race" is not physical but spiritual – a competition in purifying the soul and perfecting one’s submission to Allah through unwavering adherence to the pillars of faith and Wilayah (divine guardianship). Imam Ali (as) states, *"The most swift in good deeds are the most swift in attaining Paradise"* (Nahj al-Balagha), emphasizing that spiritual velocity lies in aligning one’s actions with divine truth.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) explains the cosmic dimensions of Paradise mentioned here symbolize the boundless mercy and knowledge granted to those who anchor their faith in Allah’s chosen guides. He states, *"The width of the Garden is the expanse of divine recognition (ma'rifah) – it expands as the heart embraces the light of the Imams"* (Tafsir al-Qummi). This reflects the Shia understanding that true belief necessitates acceptance of Imamah, for the verse specifies reward for those who "believed in Allah **and His messengers**" – a phrase the Imams interpret as including their own divinely appointed station.

Lady Fatimah (as) taught that this spiritual race is won through detachment from worldly illusions and constant remembrance of the Hereafter. Her famous supplication, *"O Allah, make my greatest concern that which You are concerned with!"* (Bihar al-Anwar), encapsulates the mindset of those striving for this Paradise. Practical steps include immersing oneself in Quranic teachings, performing obligatory acts with the presence of heart, and nurturing love for the Prophet’s purified progeny – for as Imam Ali (as) said, *"We are the gate of Allah’s mercy and the ark of salvation"* (Al-Kafi). The verse’s conclusion – "Allah grants His bounty to whom He wills" – reminds us that while effort is essential, ultimate success flows from clinging to the rope of Wilayah, through which divine grace manifests.

سورہ الحد 21 کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے ، کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ الہی معافی اور آسمانی باغ کی طرف "ریس" (سبقو) کی الہی کال کے آنٹولوجیکل اور روحانی جہتوں پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ تبریسی ، *مجس البیان *میں ، اس بات کی وضاحت کرتا ہے کہ "مقابلہ" کرنے کا لازمی نیک اعمال انجام دینے اور اندرونی خوبیوں کو کاشت کرنے میں فوری طور پر اشارہ کرتا ہے ، اور اسے دنیاوی خلفشار کے خلاف مستقل جدوجہد (جہاد النفوں) کے طور پر مرتب کرتا ہے۔ باغ کی چوڑائی کا استعارہ جو "آسمانوں اور زمین" کے برابر ہے اس کی ترجمانی جسمانی جگہ سے ماورا ہے۔ * المزان * میں تبتابائی یہ کہتے ہیں کہ اس سے الہی رحمت کی بے حد ، ہر طرف متضاد نوعیت اور اس کے بعد کی نظریاتی وسعت کی علامت ہے ، جو اللہ کی تخلیقی طاقت (کوڈراہ) کے کائناتی پیمانے کی آئینہ دار ہے۔  

اس آیت کی تفصیلات کہ جنت "ان لوگوں کے لئے تیار ہے جو اللہ اور اس کے میسینجرز پر یقین رکھتے ہیں" شیعہ الہیات کے اندر سیاق و سباق کو واضح طور پر اے ایچ ایل البائٹ کے ولیہ (سرپرستی) میں عقیدے کو گھیرے ہوئے ہے۔ جیسا کہ امام جعفر السادق کی روایات میں بیان کیا گیا ہے ، سچے عقیدے (ایمان) کو عملی اطاعت کے ساتھ مذہبی اعتقاد کو مربوط کرتے ہوئے ، اماموں کے خدائی طور پر طے شدہ اختیار کو تسلیم کرنے کی ضرورت ہے۔ یہ شیعہ اصول کے مطابق ہے کہ اللہ کے میسینجرز پر اعتقاد ان کے پاکیزہ جانشینوں سے بیعت کے بغیر نامکمل ہے ، جو حدیث ادب میں ایک مرکزی خیال ہے۔  

اختتامی جملہ - "یہ اللہ کا فضل ہے جسے وہ دیتا ہے جس کو وہ چاہتا ہے"۔ کلاسیکی تبصرہ نگاروں نے زور دیا کہ اگرچہ اللہ کا احسان خودمختار ہے ، لیکن اس کی پیشن گوئی سنت اور اماموں کی تعلیمات پر عمل پیرا ہونے کے ذریعہ اس کی مرضی کے ساتھ صف بندی کی جاتی ہے۔ فقہی طور پر ، یہ آیت طوالی (اے ایچ ایل ال بیت سے پیار کرنے) اور تباری (ان کے دشمنوں سے الگ ہوجانے) کے بارے میں شیعہ افہام و تفہیم کو تقویت بخشتی ہے۔ اس طرح ، معافی کی طرف "نسل" تھاقالین (قرآن اور اہل البائٹ) کی تعلیمات میں لنگر انداز ہونے والے روحانی اور اخلاقی فضیلت کا ایک جامع حصول بن جاتی ہے ، جو نظریہ ، عقیدت اور الہی فضل کی شیعہ ترکیب کی عکاسی کرتی ہے۔
21.layer3_urdu:
سورہ الحدید کی 21 ویں آیت میں ، قرآن مجید کی "معافی کی طرف دوڑ" کی کال اور ایک کائناتی پیمانے پر جنت جدید شیعہ فکر میں طاقتور طور پر گونجتی ہے۔ آیت اللہ ناصر مکریم شیرازی جیسے ہم عصر اسکالرز اس "نسل" پر خوشنودی کے خلاف متحرک ، اجتماعی روحانی اور اخلاقی جدوجہد (جہاد النف) کے طور پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ "آسمانوں اور زمین کی طرح چوڑا" باغ کی آیت کی منظر کشی سائنسی عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے: ماہر فلکی طبیعیات مشاہدہ کائنات کو تقریبا 93 93 بلین نوری سال قطر کے طور پر بیان کرتے ہیں ، جو انسانی حدود سے تجاوز کرنے والے الہی سخاوت کا ایک استعارہ ہے۔ اسکالر ڈاکٹر محمد علی شومالی نے نوٹ کیا کہ یہ امام علی کی اس تعلیم کا آئینہ دار ہے کہ "اللہ کی رحمت اس کے غضب سے کہیں زیادہ مبہم ہے ،" مومنین پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ وہ ذاتی ترقی کو عالمگیر ہمدردی کے ساتھ سیدھ میں رکھیں۔  

معاشرتی طور پر ، آیت کی عجلت کا اطلاق عالمی بحرانوں پر ہوتا ہے۔ گرینڈ آیت اللہ حسین اسماعیل الساڈر نے "ریسنگ" کو آب و ہوا کے انصاف ، غربت کے خاتمے ، اور بین الاقوامی سطح پر یکجہتی کے لئے متحرک کرنے کی ترجمانی کی ہے ، جو اللہ کے میسینجرز پر حقیقی عقیدے کی عکاسی کرتی ہے ، جنہوں نے عالمی سطح پر انسانی وقار کو چیمپیئن بنایا۔ فلسفیانہ طور پر ، جنت کی "چوڑائی" تنگ عالمی نظریات کو چیلنج کرتی ہے ، جس سے مسلمانوں کو تکثیریت سے مشغول ہونے کی ترغیب ملتی ہے۔ اسلامی کالج کے ڈاکٹر ربیکا ماسٹرٹن نے اس کو مذہبی استثنیٰ سے متعلق عصری مباحثوں سے جوڑ دیا ہے ، اور اس آیت کی شمولیت پر بحث کرتے ہوئے - "ان لوگوں کے لئے تیار کیا گیا ہے جو یقین رکھتے ہیں"۔  

پولرائزیشن کے دور میں ، یہ آیت فعال امید کے لئے ایک منشور بن جاتی ہے: روحانی خواہش معاشرتی ذمہ داری کے ساتھ مل گئی۔ جیسا کہ ایرانی فلسفی عبدولکریم سوروش نے مشاہدہ کیا ، "اللہ کا فضل" نہ صرف اس کے بعد ہی نہیں بلکہ انسانیت کی اخلاقی افق کو بڑھانے کی صلاحیت میں ظاہر ہوتا ہے۔

اس گہری آیت میں ، اللہ مومنوں کو دعوت دیتا ہے کہ وہ آسمانوں اور زمین پر پھیلے ہوئے الہی معافی اور ایک جنت کی طرف جلدی کریں۔ اہل بیت (ان پر امن ہے) یہ سکھاتا ہے کہ یہ "نسل" جسمانی نہیں بلکہ روحانی ہے - روح کو پاک کرنے اور کسی کے ساتھ اللہ کے سامنے جمع ہونے کا ایک مقابلہ عقیدے اور ولیہ (الہی سرپرستی) کے ستونوں کی غیر متزلزل پابندی کے ذریعے۔ امام علی (ع) نے کہا ہے ، * "اچھ deeds ے کاموں میں سب سے زیادہ تیز رفتار جنت کے حصول میں سب سے زیادہ تیز رفتار ہے" * (ناہج البالاگھا) ، اس بات پر زور دیتے ہوئے کہ روحانی رفتار الہی سچائی کے ساتھ کسی کے اعمال کو سیدھ میں کرنے میں مضمر ہے۔

امام جعفر السادق (ع) نے یہاں مذکور جنت کے کائناتی جہتوں کی وضاحت کی ہے جو اللہ کے منتخب کردہ رہنماؤں پر اپنے عقیدے کو لنگر انداز کرنے والوں کو بے حد رحمت اور علم کی علامت ہیں۔ انہوں نے کہا ، "باغ کی چوڑائی الہی پہچان (مافرفہ) کی وسعت ہے-یہ اس وقت پھیلتا ہے جب دل نے اماموں کی روشنی کو قبول کیا ہے" * (طافسیر الکومی)۔ اس سے شیعہ کی تفہیم کی عکاسی ہوتی ہے کہ حقیقی عقیدے کو امامہ کی قبولیت کی ضرورت ہے ، کیونکہ آیت میں ان لوگوں کے لئے انعام کی وضاحت کی گئی ہے جو "اللہ ** اور اس کے میسینجرز ** پر یقین رکھتے ہیں" - ایک جملہ اماموں کی ترجمانی ان کے اپنے الہی مقرر کردہ اسٹیشن سمیت ہے۔

لیڈی فاطمہ (ع) نے سکھایا کہ یہ روحانی نسل دنیاوی فریبوں سے لاتعلقی اور اس کے بعد کی مستقل یاد سے جیت جاتی ہے۔ اس کی مشہور التجا ، "" اے اللہ ، میری سب سے بڑی تشویش کا باعث بنتی ہے جس سے آپ کا تعلق ہے! " عملی اقدامات میں قرآنی تعلیمات میں خود کو غرق کرنا ، دل کی موجودگی کے ساتھ لازمی کام انجام دینا ، اور نبی کی پاکیزہ اولاد سے محبت کی پرورش کرنا شامل ہے-جیسا کہ امام علی (ع) نے کہا ، "ہم اللہ کی رحمت کا دروازہ اور نجات کا صندوق ہیں" * (الکفی)۔ آیت کا یہ نتیجہ - "اللہ اپنے فضل سے جس سے وہ چاہتا ہے" دیتا ہے " - ہمیں یاد دلاتا ہے کہ اگرچہ کوشش ضروری ہے ، حتمی کامیابی ولیہ کی رسی سے چمٹے رہنے سے بہتی ہے ، جس کے ذریعے خدائی فضل ظاہر ہوتا ہے۔
21.layer5:
Both Shia and Sunni scholarly traditions emphasize the verse’s call to spiritual competition (*sabiqū*) for divine forgiveness and Paradise, interpreting its cosmic imagery as symbolizing Allah’s boundless mercy. Al-Tabrisi (Shia) and Ibn Kathir (Sunni) concur that the Garden’s vastness reflects the transcendence of divine reward, surpassing human comprehension. Al-Tabari and Al-Tusi both highlight the verse’s ethical imperative: believers must actively pursue righteousness, aligning with the Quranic theme of moral urgency.  

A key divergence arises in defining “those who believed in Allah and His messengers.” Shia exegetes like Al-Qummi and Al-Tabatabai often contextualize this within the framework of *walāyah* (allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt), viewing belief as incomplete without recognition of Imam Ali and the Imams as spiritual and temporal successors to the Prophet. In contrast, Sunni commentators such as Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi interpret the phrase more broadly, focusing on adherence to prophetic teachings without explicit linkage to post-prophetic leadership. This reflects the Shia theological emphasis on Imamate as a divine institution integral to faith.  

The phrase “He gives to whom He wills” is universally acknowledged as affirming Allah’s sovereignty, yet interpretations differ subtly. Al-Tabatabai (Shia) ties divine grace to human preparedness through obedience and love for the Ahl al-Bayt, whereas Al-Razi (Sunni) stresses God’s unconditional prerogative, independent of human action. These distinctions subtly influence devotional practices: Shia traditions may prioritize rituals reinforcing allegiance to the Imams, while Sunni practices emphasize individual piety and communal unity.  

Historically, these differences stem from early theological debates about religious authority after the Prophet’s death. Shia exegesis developed within a paradigm prioritizing the Prophet’s household as guardians of esoteric knowledge, while Sunni scholarship focused on preserving the *ummah’s* unity through consensus and textual literalism. Both traditions, however, share a core commitment to the verse’s central message: the boundless mercy of Allah awaits those who earnestly strive toward faith and virtue.
21.layer5_urdu:
شیعہ اور سنی علمی دونوں روایات الہی معافی اور جنت کے ل spiritual آیت کی روحانی مسابقت (*سبیق*) پر زور دیتے ہیں ، اور اس کی کائناتی منظر کشی کی ترجمانی اللہ کی بے حد رحمت کی علامت ہیں۔ الاتبریسی (شیعہ) اور ابن کتھیر (سنی) نے اتفاق کیا ہے کہ باغ کی وسعت انسانی فہم کو پیچھے چھوڑ کر خدائی انعام کے عبور کی عکاسی کرتی ہے۔ التباری اور التوسی دونوں آیت کی اخلاقی لازمی کو اجاگر کرتے ہیں: مومنین کو اخلاقی عجلت کے قرآنی موضوع کے ساتھ صف بندی کرتے ہوئے ، نیک نیت کو فعال طور پر حاصل کرنا چاہئے۔  

ایک اہم موڑ "ان لوگوں کی وضاحت کرنے میں پیدا ہوتا ہے جو اللہ اور اس کے میسینجرز پر یقین رکھتے ہیں۔" شیعہ القومی اور الاتاباتابائی کی طرح استثنیٰ کرتے ہیں اکثر اس کو * والیہ * (اہل البیت سے بیعت) کے فریم ورک کے اندر سیاق و سباق دیتے ہیں ، اور عقیدہ کو امام علی کی پہچان کے بغیر نامکمل سمجھتے ہیں اور نبی صلی اللہ علیہ وسلم کے روحانی اور عارضی جانشینوں کے طور پر۔ اس کے برعکس ، سنی مفسرین جیسے القوروبی اور الراجی اس جملے کی زیادہ وسیع پیمانے پر تشریح کرتے ہیں ، اور اس کے بعد پیش گوئی کی قیادت سے واضح رابطے کے بغیر پیشن گوئی کی تعلیمات پر عمل پیرا ہونے پر توجہ دیتے ہیں۔ یہ ایمان کے لئے ایک الہی ادارہ کے طور پر امامیٹ پر شیعہ مذہبی زور کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔  

"وہ جس کو وہ چاہتا ہے" کے فقرے کو عالمی سطح پر اللہ کی خودمختاری کی تصدیق کے طور پر تسلیم کیا جاتا ہے ، پھر بھی تشریحات بالکل مختلف ہیں۔ الاتعباتابائی (شیعہ) اے ایچ ایل ال بیت کے لئے اطاعت اور محبت کے ذریعہ انسانی تیاری سے الہی فضل سے تعلق رکھتے ہیں ، جبکہ الراجی (سنی) خدا کے غیر مشروط تعصب پر زور دیتے ہیں ، جو انسانی عمل سے آزاد ہیں۔ یہ امتیازات عقیدت مندانہ طریقوں پر پوری طرح اثر انداز ہوتے ہیں: شیعہ روایات اماموں سے بیعت کرنے والی رسومات کو ترجیح دے سکتی ہیں ، جبکہ سنی کے طریق کار انفرادی تقویٰ اور فرقہ وارانہ اتحاد پر زور دیتے ہیں۔  

تاریخی طور پر ، یہ اختلافات نبی کی موت کے بعد مذہبی اتھارٹی کے بارے میں ابتدائی مذہبی مباحثوں سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں۔ شیعہ کی توثیق ایک مثال کے اندر تیار ہوئی ہے جس میں نبی کے گھر والوں کو باطنی علم کے سرپرست کی حیثیت سے ترجیح دی گئی ہے ، جبکہ سنی اسکالرشپ نے اتفاق رائے اور متنی لفظی کے ذریعہ * امت کے اتحاد کو محفوظ رکھنے پر توجہ دی ہے۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات آیت کے مرکزی پیغام کے لئے بنیادی عزم کا اشتراک کرتی ہیں: اللہ کی بے حد رحمت ان لوگوں کا منتظر ہے جو عقیدے اور فضیلت کی طرف پوری کوشش کرتے ہیں۔
21.summary: According to classical exegesis in Tafsir al-Mizan, ing "the heavens and earth" is interpreted as transcending physical spatiality; Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* posits this signifies the boundless, all-encompassing nature of divine mercy and the ontological vastness of the hereafter, which mirrors the cosmic scale of Allah’s creative power (qudrah). In Surah Al-Hadid 57:21, Allah invites believers to hasten toward *maghfira* (forgiveness) and a *jannah* (Paradise) as vast as the heavens and earth. The verse’s urgent tone—using the command *sabiqu* (race)—emphasizes proactive spiritual striving. Historical context suggests this Medinan verse addressed early Muslims transitioning from persecution to community-building, reminding them that material success must not overshadow eternal goals. Imam Ali (as) states, *"The most swift in good deeds are the most swift in attaining Paradise"* (Nahj al-Balagha), emphasizing that spiritual velocity lies in aligning one’s actions with divine truth. This verse calls Muslims to balance worldly responsibilities with spiritual priorities.
21.layer2short: In interpreting Surah al-Hadid 21, classical Shia exegetes emphasise the ontological and spiritual dimensions of the divine call to "race" (sabiqoo) toward divine forgiveness and the celestial Garden. Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, elucidates that the imperative to "compete" denotes urgency in performing righteous deeds and cultivating inner virtues, framing it as a perpetual struggle (jihad al-nafs) against worldly distractions. The metaphor of the Garden’s width equalling "the heavens and earth" is interpreted as transcending physical spatiality; Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* posits this signifies the boundless, all-encompassing nature of divine mercy and the ontological vastness of the hereafter, which mirrors the cosmic scale of Allah’s creative power (qudrah).

22.layer1:
Surah al-Hadid verse 22 offers profound insight into divine decree (qadar) and Allah’s eternal knowledge. The verse states that no calamity—whether earthly events like natural disasters or personal trials like illness or loss—occurs except that it was already recorded in a heavenly "kitab" (register) before its manifestation. This "kitab" is understood in Shia tafsir as the Preserved Tablet (al-Lawh al-Mahfuz), the comprehensive record of Allah’s knowledge encompassing all creation. The phrase "min qabl an nabra’aha" (before We bring it into being) emphasizes that Allah’s foreknowledge isn’t bound by time; His awareness precedes all events, yet human free will remains intact within this framework.  

Historical accounts note this verse comforted early Muslims facing persecution, reinforcing that hardships weren’t random but part of a divine plan. Key terms like "musiba" (disaster) derive from the root "aṣ-ṣa-ba," implying a "striking" event meant to test faith or spur spiritual growth. The verse’s closing—"indeed that, for Allah, is easy"—highlights His absolute sovereignty over creation’s complexities.  

For contemporary believers, this verse cultivates trust (tawakkul) during adversity. It teaches that trials aren’t punishments but opportunities for reflection and closeness to Allah. Modern applications include resisting despair by viewing challenges through the lens of divine wisdom—whether personal setbacks, global crises, or societal injustices. Shia theology emphasizes balancing acceptance of qadar with proactive effort (tawassul, dua, seeking justice), as seen in the lives of the Ahlul Bayt, who endured immense suffering yet remained steadfast. By internalizing this verse, Muslims can navigate life’s uncertainties with resilience, knowing nothing escapes Allah’s plan while striving to align their actions with His will.
22.layer2:
In Surah al-Hadid (57:22), the Qur’an affirms that all earthly calamities and personal tribulations are pre-recorded in a divine register (kitab) prior to their occurrence. Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt, interpret this "book" as an expression of Allah’s eternal knowledge (ʿilm al-ghayb) inscribed in the Preserved Tablet (al-Lawh al-Mahfuz). As Tabatabai elucidates in *Al-Mizan*, this verse underscores the principle of divine qada (decree) and qadar (predestination), while simultaneously affirming human free will (ikhtiyar). The apparent tension between preordination and human agency is resolved through the Shia theological framework of *amr bayn al-amrayn* (a matter between two matters), wherein Allah’s foreknowledge encompasses all possibilities without coercively determining outcomes—a concept traced to Imam Jafar al-Sadiq’s teachings.

Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* emphasizes that the verse’s concluding phrase—“indeed that, for Allah, is easy”—highlights divine omnipotence over cosmic and existential affairs, rejecting any notion of chance or randomness in creation. Calamities, in this view, serve as tests (ibtila) aligned with divine wisdom (hikma), intended to purify believers or elevate spiritual ranks. Shia tradition further links this cosmic order to the ontological role of the Imams as manifest signs (ayat) of Allah’s knowledge, with narrations indicating their awareness of the Preserved Tablet’s contents.

Jurisprudentially, this verse underpins the Shia ethic of patient perseverance (sabr) amid trials, as well as the doctrinal obligation to submit to divine will without fatalism. The balance between preordination and accountability remains central to Shia theodicy, harmonizing Allah’s absolute sovereignty with the moral responsibility of creation—a synthesis epitomized in the school’s adherence to divine justice (ʿadl) as a core theological tenet.

In Surah Al-Hadid 57:22, the Quran affirms that all events—whether global catastrophes or personal trials—are divinely recorded in a cosmic "register" (kitab) before their occurrence. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, emphasize this verse’s balance between divine foreknowledge and human agency. While disasters are preordained in Allah’s knowledge, Shirazi notes this doesn’t negate causality in the natural world or human responsibility to mitigate harm. For instance, climate-linked disasters like floods or wildfires, while part of a cosmic design, are intensified by human choices—a theme echoed by scholars like Sayyed Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah, who linked environmental ethics to Quranic stewardship of Earth.  

Modern scientific frameworks, such as chaos theory or quantum indeterminacy, challenge rigid determinism, yet align with the verse’s assertion of a "register" by suggesting underlying order within apparent randomness. Philosophically, this verse addresses theodicy: suffering isn’t arbitrary but exists within a divine plan that human intellect may grasp only partially. Socially, it resonates in crises like the COVID-19 pandemic, urging communities to blend faith in qadar (divine decree) with proactive resilience—a duality stressed by scholars like Dr. Liyakat Takim, who highlights Shia Islam’s emphasis on *tawakkul* (trust in God) paired with practical effort.  

Interfaith dialogues find common ground here; Jewish and Christian theologians similarly reconcile providence with free will. Multiculturally, the verse invites reflection on shared human vulnerability amid disasters, fostering solidarity. Ultimately, this verse bridges transcendence and immanence: while Allah’s knowledge encompasses all, humanity’s role is to navigate life’s trials with wisdom, compassion, and ethical rigor—a timeless message for an interconnected, uncertain world.

In the luminous teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them), Surah Al-Hadid 57:22 unveils profound truths about divine decree (qadar) and the spiritual purpose behind life's trials. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught that every calamity is a "mirror for the believer," reflecting hidden flaws in the soul and inviting purification. The "register" mentioned in the verse is understood by Shia scholars as the Preserved Tablet (Lawh Mahfuz), wherein Allah's eternal knowledge encompasses all events, yet human free will remains intact through the principle of *al-amr bayn al-amrayn* (a matter between two matters), as expounded by Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him).

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasized in her sermons that trials are divine gifts to elevate souls: "Allah makes afflictions descend as blessings upon His friends, and blessings descend as afflictions upon His enemies." This verse reminds believers that hardships are not random occurrences but divinely ordained tests aligned with one's spiritual capacity. Imam Sadiq (peace be upon him) explained: "When a believer understands that his calamity was already written, his heart finds rest in submission."

Practically, this verse calls for *tawakkul* (trust in Allah) and recognition of *Imamah* as the channel of divine wisdom. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) advised: "When struck by calamity, seek its remedy in dua, for it is the weapon of the believer." The Ahlul Bayt teach that true faith transforms suffering into a means of drawing nearer to Allah through patience (*sabr*) and gratitude (*shukr*). By embracing wilayah (spiritual guardianship of the Imams), believers perceive trials as opportunities to mirror the steadfastness of Hussain (peace be upon him) at Karbala, where ultimate submission to divine will unveiled eternal light from apparent darkness.

لیڈی فاطمہ (اس پر امن) نے اپنے خطبات میں اس بات پر زور دیا کہ آزمائشیں روحوں کو بلند کرنے کے لئے الہی تحائف ہیں: "اللہ مصیبتوں کو اپنے دوستوں پر برکت کے طور پر اترتا ہے ، اور برکتیں اپنے دشمنوں پر مصائب کی طرح اترتی ہیں۔" یہ آیت مومنوں کو یاد دلاتی ہے کہ مشکلات بے ترتیب واقعات نہیں ہیں بلکہ خدائی طور پر مقررہ ٹیسٹ کسی کی روحانی صلاحیت کے ساتھ منسلک ہیں۔ امام صادق (اس پر امن) نے وضاحت کی: "جب کوئی مومن سمجھتا ہے کہ اس کی تباہی پہلے ہی لکھی گئی ہے تو ، اس کا دل پیش کرنے میں آرام کرتا ہے۔"

عملی طور پر ، اس آیت میں * توقکول * (اللہ پر اعتماد) اور * امامہ * کو الہی حکمت کے چینل کے طور پر تسلیم کرنے کا مطالبہ کیا گیا ہے۔ امام علی (اس پر امن کریں) نے مشورہ دیا: "جب تباہی سے ٹکراؤ ، تو اس کا علاج داؤ میں حاصل کریں ، کیونکہ یہ مومن کا ہتھیار ہے۔" اہل بیت یہ سکھاتے ہیں کہ صبر (*صابر*) اور شکرگزار (*شوکر*) کے ذریعہ اللہ کے قریب جانے کے ایک ذریعہ میں حقیقی عقیدے کو تکلیف پہنچتی ہے۔ ولیہ (اماموں کی روحانی سرپرستی) کو گلے لگا کر ، مومنین کو کربالا میں حسین (اس پر سلامتی) کے ثابت قدمی کی عکسبندی کے مواقع کے طور پر آزمائشوں کا احساس ہوتا ہے ، جہاں الہی کے سامنے حتمی طور پر پیش آنے سے ابدی روشنی کو اندھیرے سے نقاب کشائی ہوگی۔
22.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Hadid 57:22, both Shia and Sunni scholars converge on the theological principle of divine foreknowledge and predestination (qadar), affirming that all events – including earthly calamities and personal trials – are pre-recorded in Allah’s eternal register (al-Lawh al-Mahfuz). Tabari (Sunni) and Tabatabai (Shia) alike emphasize this as a manifestation of Allah’s omniscience and omnipotence, with Tabatabai noting in *Al-Mizan* that such preordination reflects divine wisdom (ḥikma) rather than arbitrary compulsion. Similarly, Ibn Kathir (Sunni) and Tabrisi (Shia) in *Majma al-Bayan* agree that this verse encourages believers to cultivate patience (ṣabr) and trust in divine wisdom during adversity.

Divergences emerge in theological implications. Sunni commentators like Qurtubi and Razi often frame predestination within the Ashʿari doctrine of occasionalism, stressing Allah’s absolute agency while reconciling human responsibility through the concept of kasb (acquisition). In contrast, Shia exegetes such as Tusi (*At-Tibyan*) and Qummi highlight the coexistence of divine decree with human free will (ikhtiyār), arguing that preordination does not negate moral accountability. Tabatabai further contextualizes this within the Shia paradigm of Imamah, suggesting that trials may serve to purify believers’ allegiance to divinely guided leadership.

These distinctions influence practical spirituality: Sunni interpretations often focus on unconditional submission to Allah’s will, while Shia perspectives may view hardships as tests of fidelity to sacred authority. Historically, these differences stem from early theological debates about divine justice and human agency, with Shia thought influenced by the Muʿtazili emphasis on rational justice and the Imam’s role as a spiritual intermediary. Both traditions, however, unite in using this verse to affirm Allah’s transcendence and the purposeful nature of existence, avoiding fatalism by linking divine knowledge to a greater cosmic design.

مذہبی مضمرات میں تغیرات ابھرتے ہیں۔ سنی کے مبصرین جیسے قربانی اور رازی اکثر کبھی کبھار کے اشاری نظریہ کے اندر پیش گوئی کرتے ہیں ، اور اللہ کی مطلق ایجنسی پر زور دیتے ہوئے کے اے ایس بی (حصول) کے تصور کے ذریعے انسانی ذمہ داری کو صلح کرتے ہوئے۔ اس کے برعکس ، شیعہ ایگیٹس جیسے توسی (*ایٹ-تبیان*) اور قمی نے انسانی آزادانہ مرضی (Ikhtiyhr) کے ساتھ الہی فرمان کے بقائے باہمی کو اجاگر کیا ، اور یہ استدلال کیا کہ پیشگی اخلاقی احتساب کی نفی نہیں کرتی ہے۔ تبتابائی نے اس کو مزید امامہ کے شیعہ تمثیل کے اندر سیاق و سباق میں مبتلا کردیا ، اور یہ تجویز کیا گیا ہے کہ آزمائشیں مومنین کی الہی رہنمائی قیادت سے وفاداری کو پاک کرنے میں معاون ثابت ہوسکتی ہیں۔

Surah al-Hadid verse 22 offers profound insight into divine decree (qadar) and Allah’s eternal knowledge. The verse states that no calamity—whether earthly events like natural disasters or personal trials like illness or loss—occurs except that it was already recorded in a heavenly "kitab" (register) before its manifestation. This "kitab" is understood in Shia tafsir as the Preserved Tablet (al-Lawh al-Mahfuz), the comprehensive record of Allah’s knowledge encompassing all creation. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught that every calamity is a "mirror for the believer," reflecting hidden flaws in the soul and inviting purification. By internalizing this verse, Muslims can navigate life’s uncertainties with resilience, knowing nothing escapes Allah’s plan while striving to align their actions with His will.
22.layer2short: In Surah al-Hadid (57:22), the Qur’an affirms that all earthly calamities and personal tribulations are pre-recorded in a divine register (kitab) prior to their occurrence. Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt, interpret this "book" as an expression of Allah’s eternal knowledge (ʿilm al-ghayb) inscribed in the Preserved Tablet (al-Lawh al-Mahfuz). As Tabatabai elucidates in *Al-Mizan*, this verse underscores the principle of divine qada (decree) and qadar (predestination), while simultaneously affirming human free will (ikhtiyar). The apparent tension between preordination and human agency is resolved through the Shia theological framework of *amr bayn al-amrayn* (a matter between two matters), wherein Allah’s foreknowledge encompasses all possibilities without coercively determining outcomes—a concept traced to Imam Jafar al-Sadiq’s teachings.

23.layer1:
This verse from Surah al-Hadid offers profound guidance on emotional balance, urging believers to avoid extremes of grief over losses or arrogance in success. The phrase *"li-kayla ta'saw ala ma fatakum"* (so you do not despair over what escapes you) addresses the human tendency to fixate on missed opportunities or material losses, while *"wa la tafrahu bima atakum"* (nor exult over what He grants you) warns against pride in worldly gains. Both conditions – despair (*asa*) and excessive joy (*faraḥ*) – are framed as spiritual traps that disconnect hearts from divine perspective.  

Historical accounts link this verse to the early Muslim community’s struggles, where fluctuating fortunes in battles and social dynamics tested their reliance on Allah. Shia tafsir scholars like Tabatabai emphasize that worldly gains and losses are transient tests, not ultimate measures of success. The verse concludes by condemning *mukhtal* (self-deluded) and *fakhoor* (boastful) attitudes – traits that Imam Ali warned against in Nahj al-Balagha, associating them with spiritual blindness.  

In modern life, this verse speaks directly to our era of instant gratification and social comparison. It teaches Muslims to cultivate *tawakkul* (trust in Allah) by accepting both blessings and trials as part of a greater divine plan. When facing job losses, health challenges, or social media-driven envy, believers are reminded that true value lies in eternal rewards, not temporary possessions. Conversely, success should inspire gratitude (*shukr*), not arrogance. By internalizing this balance – as modeled by the Ahlul Bayt in their resilience through persecution – Muslims can navigate life’s fluctuations with grace, recognizing that all circumstances are opportunities for growth in Allah’s path.
23.layer2:
In Surah Al-Hadid (57:23), Allah instructs believers to avoid excessive grief over worldly losses and unchecked pride in blessings, framing this equilibrium as a safeguard against spiritual corruption. Classical Shia exegetes emphasize this verse’s alignment with the ontological principle of *tawhid al-af’al* (divine unity in agency), wherein all events—whether perceived as gain or loss—are ultimately governed by Allah’s wisdom. As Tabatabai elucidates in *Al-Mizan*, the verse critiques the human tendency to attribute outcomes to personal effort or misfortune, rather than recognizing divine orchestration. This fosters either *ishtighal bil-makthub* (preoccupation with the ephemeral) or *ghaflah* (heedlessness) from the eternal.

Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* contextualizes the prohibition against despair (*ta’saw*) and exultation (*tafrah*) within the ethical framework of the Ahl al-Bayt, noting that Imam Ali ibn Abi Talib described worldly matters as "a shadow that will inevitably fade" (Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 28). Theologically, Shia commentators link this to the doctrine of *rida* (contentment with divine decree), which Imam Jafar al-Sadiq identified as the pinnacle of faith. Excessive grief implies rejection of *qada’* (divine destiny), while pride in blessings negates *shukr* (gratitude), both violating the covenant of servitude (*ubudiyyah*).

The verse’s condemnation of *mukhtal* (self-delusion) and *fakhur* (boastfulness) underscores the Shia ethical vision where humility before Allah’s will is inseparable from devotion to the Imams’ guidance. Jurisprudentially, this aligns with the Shia emphasis on *zuhd* (ascetic detachment) not as renunciation, but as prioritizing eternal truths over transient possessions. The verse thus serves as a microcosm of the Shia worldview: temporal trials and blessings are tests of one’s alignment with the *ma’rifah* (recognition) of Allah’s absolute sovereignty, perfected through the Walayah of the Ahl al-Bayt.
23.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Hadid 57:23 is often framed as a blueprint for emotional and spiritual resilience in an age of volatility. Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi, in his exegesis, highlights the verse’s call to transcend attachment to worldly outcomes—a theme echoed by scholars like Sayyed Muhammad Hussein Fadlallah, who linked it to cultivating *tawakkul* (trust in divine wisdom) amid modern anxieties. Psychologists such as Dr. Ali Reza Panahian integrate this teaching with cognitive behavioral principles, noting how despair over loss and arrogance in success correlate with rising rates of depression and narcissism in hyper-competitive societies.  

The verse’s warning against *mukhtal* (self-delusion) and *fakhur* (boastfulness) resonates in today’s social media culture, where curated personas fuel envy and discontent. Scholars like Dr. Liyakat Takim connect this to systemic issues: economic inequality and climate crises rooted in unchecked materialism. The Qur’anic balance—neither clinging to what’s lost nor idolizing gain—mirrors ecological principles of sustainability, urging moderation in consumption.  

Interfaith dialogues, particularly with Buddhist mindfulness and Stoic equanimity, find common ground here. The Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on *rida* (contentment) align with global philosophies advocating detachment from external validations. For multicultural societies, this verse becomes a universal ethic: resisting the "hustle culture" that glorifies excess while fostering solidarity with those marginalized by systemic inequities.  

In essence, 57:23 is a timeless antidote to modernity’s extremes—a call to anchor self-worth in spiritual purpose rather than transient gains, a vision urgently needed in a fractured world seeking meaning beyond materialism.

Imam Ali (as) taught, “The world is a corpse, and its seekers are dogs.” This metaphor warns against chasing fleeting material blessings, urging detachment (*zuhd*) as a path to spiritual freedom. The verse’s warning against despair and pride reflects the Shia emphasis on *tawakkul* (trust in Allah) and recognizing all blessings as temporary trusts (*amana*) from Him, not personal achievements.  

Imam Sadiq (as) explained this verse by stating, “Whoever is content with what Allah has allotted for him will be the richest of people.” Here, contentment (*rida*) is tied to the recognition of Divine Decree (*qadr*), a pillar of Shia theology. The “self-deluded and boastful” are those who forget their dependence on Allah’s will, neglecting the reality that true success lies in proximity to the *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) of the Ahlul Bayt.  

Lady Fatimah (as) exemplified this balance. When her inheritance was denied, she responded not with despair but with dignified reliance on Allah, stating, “Allah suffices for me, and He is the Best Disposer of affairs.” Her life embodied the verse’s wisdom: neither clinging to worldly loss nor boasting in worldly gain.  

Practical guidance lies in daily remembrance (*dhikr*) and gratitude (*shukr*). Imam Ali (as) advised, “Count your blessings as a means to draw closer to Allah, not as a reason for arrogance.” By anchoring the heart to the eternal love of the Ahlul Bayt and viewing trials as tests of faith, believers cultivate inner peace, aligning their souls with the purpose of creation: to know and worship Allah through the luminous path of the 14 Infallibles.
